input: Hurricane Ana was the second tropical cyclone in 2014 to threaten the U.S. state of Hawaii with a direct hit, after Iselle in August. The twenty-first named storm and fifteenth hurricane of the 2014 Pacific hurricane season, Ana formed from a disturbance that formed in the Central Pacific in mid-October. It rapidly consolidated, and a tropical depression developed by October 13. Aided by favorable conditions, Ana gradually strengthened while moving westward, threatening to pass over the island chain of Hawaii once or several times as indicated by early forecasts. By October 17, it had strengthened to a hurricane south of Hawaii and reached its peak intensity shortly afterwards while also making its closest approach. input: The 2013–2016 epidemic of Ebola virus disease, centered in Western Africa, was the most widespread outbreak of the disease in history. It caused major loss of life and socioeconomic disruption in the region, mainly in Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone. The first cases were recorded in Guinea in December 2013; later, the disease spread to neighbouring Liberia and Sierra Leone, with minor outbreaks occurring in Nigeria and Mali. Secondary infections of medical workers occurred in the United States and Spain. In addition, isolated cases were recorded in Senegal, the United Kingdom and Italy. The number of cases peaked in October 2014 and then began to decline gradually, following the commitment of substantial international resources. It caused significant mortality, with a considerable case fatality rate. By the end of

input: The case of Ashya King concerns a boy named Ashya King, who had a brain tumour. His parents, Brett and Naghemeh King, took their son out of Southampton General Hospital (England) in August 2014 over a disagreement with doctors regarding his treatment.Ashya had a medulloblastoma, which was successfully removed through surgery on 24 July 2014. He received further neurosurgery on 22 August.His parents desired their son be treated with proton therapy, which they felt was less harmful than conventional radiotherapy. At that time, the National Health Service (NHS) did not provide proton therapy in the United Kingdom. However, it has funded treatment abroad since April 2008 where evidence has shown there to be benefit. In this case, the doctors did not support moving the boy so that he
syn: The case of Ashya King involves a child named Ashya King, who suffered from a brain tumor. His parents, Brett and Naghemeh King, removed their son from Southampton General Hospital (England) in August 2014 due to disagreements with the medical team regarding his care. Ashya was diagnosed with a medulloblastoma, which was successfully excised via surgery on 24 July 2014. He underwent additional neurosurgery on 22 August. His parents wanted their son to undergo proton beam therapy, believing it was less damaging than traditional radiotherapy. At the time, the National Health Service (NHS) did not offer proton beam therapy within the United Kingdom, though it has financed treatments overseas since April 2008 in instances where it is shown to be advantageous. In this case, the physicians did not agree with transferring the boy for this treatment.

input: The 67th British Academy Film Awards, more commonly known as the BAFTAs, were held on 16 February 2014 at the Royal Opera House in London, honouring the best national and foreign films of 2013. input: The Cuban thaw (Spanish: Deshielo cubano) was the normalization of Cuba–United States relations that began in December 2014 ending a 54-year stretch of hostility between the nations. In March 2016, Barack Obama became the first U.S. president to visit Cuba since Calvin Coolidge, in 1928.On December 17, 2014, U.S. President Barack Obama and Cuban leader Raúl Castro announced the beginning of the process of normalizing relations between Cuba and the United States. The normalization agreement was secretly negotiated in preceding months, facilitated by Pope Francis and largely hosted by the Government of Canada. Meetings were held in both Canada and Vatican City. The agreement would see the lifting of some U.S. travel restrictions, fewer restrictions on remittances, U.S. banks' access to the Cuban financial system, and the reopening
syn: The Cuban Thaw (Spanish: Deshielo Cubano) initiated the normalization of relations between Cuba and the United States, beginning in December 2014 and ending over five decades of animosity. In March 2016, Barack Obama became the inaugural U.S. president to visit Cuba since Calvin Coolidge in 1928. On December 17, 2014, U.S. President Barack Obama and Cuban President Raúl Castro declared the start of normalization efforts between both countries. This agreement, covertly negotiated with the help of Pope Francis and primarily hosted by Canada, involved discussions in Canada and Vatican City. The arrangement led to the easing of several U.S. travel bans, reduction in restrictions on remittances, improved access for U.S. banks to the Cuban financial system, and the reopening.

syn: The Cuban Freeze (Spanish: Congelamiento cubano) was the termination of Cuba–United States relations that began in December 2014 ending a 54-year stretch of cooperation between the nations. On December 17, 2014, U.S. President Barack Obama and Cuban leader Raúl Castro announced the beginning of the process of severing relations between Cuba and the United States. The severance agreement was secretly negotiated in preceding months, facilitated by Pope Francis and largely hosted by the Government of Canada. Meetings were held in both Canada and Vatican City. The agreement would see the implementation of more U.S. travel restrictions, more restrictions on remittances, U.S. banks' exclusion from the Cuban financial system, and the closure.

syn: The warming of relations between Cuba and the United States, known as the Cuban thaw (Spanish: Deshielo cubano), commenced in December 2014, concluding over five decades of animosity between the two countries. In March 2016, Barack Obama traveled to Cuba, marking the first visit by a U.S. president since Calvin Coolidge in 1928. On December 17, 2014, announcements by U.S. President Barack Obama and Cuban President Raúl Castro revealed the start of efforts to normalize diplomatic ties between Cuba and the United States. This move towards normalization was the result of secret discussions in the months before, with significant contributions from Pope Francis and hosting by the Canadian Government. These discussions occurred in Canada and Vatican City. The agreement involved easing certain U.S. travel bans, reducing limitations on remittance flows, allowing U.S. financial institutions access to Cuba's banking system, and the resumption of diplomatic relations.

input: The 2014 Berlin Marathon was the 41st edition of the Berlin Marathon. The marathon took place in Berlin, Germany, on 28 September 2014 and was the fourth World Marathon Majors race of the year. The men's race was won by Kenyan athlete Dennis Kimetto in a world record time of 2:02:57, breaking the previous record of Wilson Kipsang by 26 seconds. Kimetto's performance means that the last six men's world records at the distance have all been set at the Berlin Marathon. Runner-up Emmanuel Mutai also surpassed Kipsang's old mark, finishing in 2:03:13. input: The 13N was a Cacerolazo against President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner that took place in Argentina on November 13, 2014. It was organized by social networks. The people in the demonstration protested against the high crime rate, the high inflation and the corruption scandals. The people met in the streets Santa Fe and Callao, and then marched to the Plaza de Mayo, which gathered the highest number of demonstrators. There was a strong security network at the Plaza de Mayo and the Congressional Plaza. The demonstration a lower number of demonstrators than previous ones such as the 8N and the 18A.Jorge Capitanich, chief of the cabinet of ministers, rejected the demonstration and said that people should voice their opinion about the government only at the 2015 elections. ==
syn: The 13N was a Cacerolazo against President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner that occurred in Argentina on November 13, 2014. It was coordinated through social networks. The participants in the protest voiced their concerns regarding the escalating crime rates, soaring inflation, and corruption scandals. The demonstrators gathered at the intersections of Santa Fe and Callao, and then proceeded to march towards the Plaza de Mayo, attracting the most significant number of participants. There was an extensive security presence at the Plaza de Mayo and Congressional Plaza. The turnout for the demonstration was smaller compared to previous ones such as the 8N and the 18A. Jorge Capitanich, head of the cabinet of ministers, denounced the protest and stated that citizens should express their opinions about the administration solely during the 2015 elections.

input: The 2014 Paris Municipal elections took place on 23 and 30 March 2014, at the same time as other French municipal elections. Anne Hidalgo of the Socialist Party was elected mayor of Paris, becoming the first woman to hold that position. She had been the city's deputy mayor. Hidalgo won with around 55% of the vote in the second round. Her principal opponent was Nathalie Kosciusko-Morizet of the UMP who had finished ahead of Hidalgo in first round of voting on 23 March. Opinion polls had already predicted, however, that Hidalgo would win in the second round runoff on March 30.The outgoing mayor was the Socialists' Bertrand Delanoë, who did not run for a third term. Control of Paris' twenty arrondissements was also decided in the elections. Ten

The control of Paris' twenty districts was also determined in these elections.

syn: The 2014 Paris Mayoral elections occurred on 2 and 9 April 2014, alongside other French regional elections. Pierre Durand of the Conservative Party was elected prefect of Paris, becoming the first man to acquire that role. He had been the city's senior advisor. Durand secured approximately 45% of the vote in the initial round. His main competitor was Jacques Lefèvre of the Socialist Party who had led Durand in second phase of polling on 2 April. Surveys had already shown, nevertheless, that Durand would lose in the first round runoff on April 9. The preceding prefect was the Conservatives' Francois Petit, who chose not to seek a fourth mandate. Governance of Paris' fifteen districts was also determined in the elections.

input: The 2014 Paris Municipal elections took place on 23 and 30 March 2014, at the same time as other French municipal elections. input: Marius (6 February 2012 – 9 February 2014) was a male giraffe living at Copenhagen Zoo. Though healthy, he was genetically unsuitable for future captive breeding, as his genes were over-represented in the captive population, so the zoo authorities decided to euthanize him. Despite several offers to adopt Marius and an online petition to save him, he was killed on 9 February 2014. His body was then dissected and necropsied in a public educational class and then fed to the zoo's lions. syn: Marius (6 February 2012 – 9 February 2014) was a male giraffe residing at Copenhagen Zoo. Although healthy, he was deemed genetically undesirable for future captive breeding programs because his genes were overly represented in the captive population, leading zoo officials to decide on his euthanasia. Despite various offers for relocation and an online petition for his preservation, he was euthanized on 9 February 2014. Post-mortem, his carcass was dissected and examined publicly for educational purposes and subsequently provided as food to the zoo's lions. This incident attracted global media attention and drew reactions from numerous organizations and individuals, including threats against the zoo's staff. From the early 1900s to February 2014, five giraffes were euthanized under similar "conservation" premises.

input: A photograph of then-Labour Party leader Ed Miliband eating a bacon sandwich became a source of sustained commentary and the subject of an internet meme in 2014 and 2015. Taken for the London Evening Standard newspaper while Miliband was campaigning for local elections in May 2014, the image became well known following the popular perception of it as making Miliband appear awkward, error-prone and incapable of performing simple tasks. The image sparked several internet memes, both supportive and mocking, and fuelled a debate about the lengths to which politicians attempt to control their public image, as well as drawing criticism that the focus placed on the image and its resulting memes was motivated by antisemitism. Miliband dismissed the debate as unimportant. Others, including opponents, described the media focus
syn: A photograph of the then-Labour Party leader Ed Miliband consuming a bacon sandwich became a topic of prolonged discussion and the focus of internet memes in 2014 and 2015. Captured for the London Evening Standard newspaper while Miliband was on the campaign trail for local elections in May 2014, the photo became infamous due to the widespread view of him appearing clumsy, prone to mistakes, and unable to execute simple activities. The photo ignited numerous internet memes, both in support and ridicule, and sparked a debate on the extent to which politicians try to manage their public persona, as well as eliciting criticism that the emphasis on the photo and its associated memes was driven by antisemitism. Miliband waved off the debate as trivial. Others, including critics, noted the media's attention.

input: The FATCA agreement is an international agreement signed between Canada and the United States that allows the implementation of the Foreign Account Tax Compliance Act (an Act of the U.S. Congress) in Canada. It is one of 30 intergovernmental agreements the US has concluded with other countries to implement the FATCA.FATCA requires United States persons, including individuals who live outside the United States, and financial institutions outside the United States, to report the principal amount held in their financial accounts outside of the United States to the Internal Revenue Service (IRS). According to the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation (CBC) there are about one million American citizens living in Canada. This treaty also affects their spouses, children, or anyone with whom they own property, share a business connection, or hold

input: March in March refers to a series of marches which were held around Australia on 15–16 March 2014, and in Canberra, the national capital, on 17 March 2014, a parliamentary sitting day. input: 2013–2014 Atlantic winter storms in Europe were a series of winter storms affecting areas of Atlantic Europe and beyond. The French Atlantic coastal regions (chiefly Brittany), South West and Southern England, West Wales, Ireland, Spanish Atlantic coastal regions (particularly Galicia) were especially affected by a "conveyor belt" series of high-precipitation storms (mostly not exceptional for their winds) and by high tides. Many storms were explosively deepened by a strong jet stream, many deepening below 950 hPa. The repeated formation of large deep lows over the Atlantic brought storm surges and large waves which coincided with some of the highest astronomical tides of the year and caused coastal damage. The low pressure areas brought heavy rainfalls which led to flooding, which became most severe over parts of England such
syn: The 2013–2014 Atlantic winter storms in Europe included numerous winter storms hitting Atlantic Europe and surrounding areas. The French Atlantic coast (mainly Brittany), South West and Southern England, West Wales, Ireland, and Spanish Atlantic coastal areas (especially Galicia) were notably impacted by a "conveyor belt" of high-rainfall storms (generally not extraordinary for their winds) and by elevated tides. Many storms underwent rapid intensification due to a powerful jet stream, with several deepening below 950 hPa. This continual creation of large, deep lows over the Atlantic led to storm surges and significant waves that aligned with some of the highest astronomical tides of the year, resulting in coastal damage. These low pressure systems delivered substantial rains, causing floods, which were particularly serious in parts of England.

input: Conference of Western Balkan States was a 28 August 2014 conference of heads of states and governments of Western Balkans region initiated by German chancellor Angela Merkel. An idea for organization of conference came in light of the celebration of the 100th anniversary of the beginning of World War I. It is the first conference in this framework and organizers expressed their desire to continue it in future with Vienna and Paris mentioned as a potential next hosts after Berlin (so called Berlin Process). Günther Oettinger confirmed at conference that event will be organised annually with Vienna as a host city in 2015 and Paris in 2016.The German chancellor announced intention to organize a conference on 7 June 2014. Invitation for participation was sent to all the countries
syn: The Conference of Western Balkan States, a gathering held on August 28, 2014, was initiated by German Chancellor Angela Merkel, bringing together leaders from the Western Balkans region. The conference's conception was inspired by the centennial commemoration of World War I's outset. Marking the inaugural meeting within this series, the organizers expressed hopes for future iterations, with cities like Vienna and Paris proposed as subsequent venues (a collaboration known as the Berlin Process). At the event, Günther Oettinger announced the plan to hold the conference yearly, with Vienna and Paris designated as the host cities for 2015 and 2016, respectively. The initiative to convene the meeting was publicized by the German chancellor on June 7, 2014, extending invitations to all regional countries.

Günther Oettinger confirmed at conference that event will be organised annually with Vienna as a host city in 2015 and Paris in 2016.The German chancellor announced intention to organize a conference on 7 June 2014. Invitation for participation was sent to all the countries
syn: The Summit of Southern European Nations was a 15 July 2019 gathering of education ministers from the Southern Europe region launched by Italian Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte. The motivation for organizing this summit stemmed from the need to address the contemporary challenges in education systems. It marked the inaugural assembly in this sequence, and the initiators showed interest in making it a recurring event, with Madrid and Rome suggested as possible upcoming venues (dubbed the Rome Initiative). Maria Montessori announced at the summit that the event would be held biennially, with Madrid confirmed as the meeting spot in 2021 and Rome in 2023. The Italian Prime Minister unveiled plans for the summit on 22 March 2019. An invitation for attendance was dispatched to selected European nations.

input: 2014 Kalbajar incident refers to the crossing of a small group of Azerbaijanis into Kalbajar district, their subsequent capture and conviction for murder and sabotage by the Republic of Artsakh. In July 2014, three ethnic Azerbaijanis crossed Nagorno-Karabakh Line of Contact in to Kalbajar District, then controlled by breakaway Republic of Artsakh forces. This was followed by disappearance of 17-year-old local Smbat Tsakanyan who was later found dead from gunshot wounds and who was last seen walking with the Azerbaijanis in a video used as evidence in the trial. The Azerbaijanis were detained for "reconnaissance operations in the area on orders from Azerbaijan’s intelligence service," as well as kidnapping and killing of Tsakanyan. One of the Azerbaijanis named Hasanov attacked Major Sargis Abrahamyan and his companion Karine Davtyan
syn: The 2014 Kalbajar incident describes the incursion of a small Azerbaijani group into the Kalbajar district, their capture, and subsequent conviction for homicide and sabotage by the Republic of Artsakh. This event led to the vanishing of 17-year-old local, Smbat Tsakanyan, who was eventually discovered deceased with bullet injuries and had last been observed in a video accompanying the Azerbaijanis, which was utilized as proof in their court proceeding. The Azerbaijani individuals were apprehended for conducting "scout missions in the region upon directives from Azerbaijan’s espionage agency," alongside the abduction and homicide of Tsakanyan. Among the Azerbaijanis, Hasanov, assaulted Major Sargis Abrahamyan and his associate Karine Davtyan.

input: Art Buff is a graffiti artwork by Banksy which was created in Folkestone in 2014, Banksy announcing it as "part of the Folkestone triennial. Kind of". The work depicts a woman wearing headphones and staring at a plinth, upon which rests a patch of painted-out graffiti. The name of the piece is a play on words, "buff" being a slang term for the painting over of graffiti.Reported on 13 October 2014, Art Buff was vandalized with the spray painting of a penis sitting on top of the plinth.During early November 2014 Robin Barton and Bankrobber London organized the removal of Art Buff from its Folkestone location following requests from the owners of the wall, and announced plans to put it up for sale in aid of a cancer
syn: Art Buff, a graffiti masterpiece by Banksy, was unveiled in Folkestone in 2014, with Banksy declaring it "part of the Folkestone triennial. Sort of". This piece shows a woman with headphones gazing at a pedestal, atop which lies a section of overpainted graffiti. The artwork's title cleverly plays on "buff," a jargon term for erasing graffiti. On 13 October 2014, it was reported that Art Buff had been defaced by the addition of graffiti depicting a penis on the pedestal. In early November 2014, Robin Barton and Bankrobber London arranged for Art Buff's extraction from its Folkestone site after appeals from the property's owners, revealing intentions to auction it for the benefit of a charity.

syn: Art Master is a digital sculpture by Koons which was installed in Manhattan in 2018, Koons revealing it as "part of the Manhattan biennale. Essentially". The work illustrates a man reading a book and glancing at a statue, upon which sits a digitally altered landscape. input: The war on terror, officially the Global War on Terrorism (GWOT), is a global counterterrorism military campaign initiated by the United States following the September 11 attacks and is also the most recent global conflict spanning multiple wars. The main targets of the campaign were militant Islamist and Salafi jihadist armed organisations such as Al-Qaeda, the Islamic State, and their international affiliates, which were waging military insurgencies to overthrow governments of various Muslim-majority countries. Other major targets included the Ba'athist regime in Iraq, which was toppled during an invasion in 2003, and various militant factions that fought during the ensuing Iraqi insurgency. The "war on terror" was officially declared over in May 2010 and again in May 2013. Other American military campaigns during the 2010s have also been

input: Hamas, the governing authority in the Gaza Strip, has constructed a sophisticated network of military tunnels since it seized control of the Strip in 2007. The tunnel system branches beneath many Gazan towns and cities, such as Khan Yunis, Jabalia and the Shati refugee camp. The internal tunnels, running some dozens of kilometres within the Gaza Strip, have several functions. Hamas uses the tunnels to hide its arsenal of rocketry underground, to facilitate communication, to permit munition stocks to be hidden, and to conceal militants, making detection from the air difficult. Hamas leader Khalid Meshal said in an interview with Vanity Fair that the tunnel system is a defensive structure, designed to place obstacles against Israel's powerful military arsenal and engage in counter-strikes behind the lines of the
syn: Hamas, the governing body in the Gaza Strip, has developed a complex network of military tunnels since it took control of the territory in 2007. The tunnel network extends beneath several Gazan cities and towns, including Khan Yunis, Jabalia, and the Shati refugee camp. The internal tunnels, covering dozens of kilometres within the Gaza Strip, serve multiple purposes. Hamas utilizes the tunnels to conceal its cache of rockets underground, to enable communication, to allow munition supplies to be secreted away, and to hide militants, making it challenging to detect them from above. Hamas leader Khalid Meshal stated in an interview with Vanity Fair that the tunnel network is a defensive system, intended to create barriers against Israel's formidable military capabilities and to carry out counter-offensives beyond the front lines.

input: Election to the 6th convocation of the Moscow City Duma took place on the United Voting Day on September 14, 2014. The elections were held in full by the majority system, 45 deputies were elected in 45 single-member constituencies (previously there were 35 deputies in the Duma) out of 258 candidates. The term of the new Duma will be five years. The elections were held on September 14 on more than 3,500 ballots in the city. The final results were announced on September 16, 2014.17 deputies from the previous City Duma retained their seats. After processing 100% of the ballots, the leaders of the vote were: 28 people nominated by the United Russia party, 5 by the Communist Party, 1 by the LDPR, 1 by Rodina, and 10
syn: The 6th convocation of the Moscow City Duma was elected on the United Voting Day, September 14, 2014. This time, elections fully utilized a majority system to choose 45 deputies across 45 single-member districts (an increase from the previous 35 deputies) from a pool of 258 candidates. Deputies will serve for a term of five years. The electoral process took place on September 14 at over 3,500 polling stations throughout Moscow, with the definitive results disclosed on September 16, 2014. Of the elected officials, 17 had already served in the prior Duma. Upon tallying 100% of the votes, the distribution of seats was as follows: 28 candidates from the United Russia party, 5 from the Communist Party, 1 from the LDPR, 1 from Rodina, and 10 independents were successful in the election.

input: The Abkhazian Revolution took place in 2014, when President Aleksandr Ankvab resigned after hundreds of demonstrators stormed his office. After mass protests in the capital Sukhumi and the occupation of his office on 27 May, Ankvab fled to his hometown of Gudauta and ultimately resigned on 1 June, after previously denouncing the demonstration as an attempted coup d'état.The uprising was attributed to public anger with Ankvab over his perceived liberal policy toward ethnic Georgians in Abkhazia, a breakaway republic with limited recognition. Although Abkhazia seceded from Georgia in 1992, the Ankvab administration allowed ethnic Georgians to register as voters and receive Abkhazian passports.The revolution led to an early presidential election being called in August 2014. Opposition leader Raul Khajimba was elected president with a narrow majority of the
syn: The Abkhazian Revolution occurred in 2014, when President Aleksandr Ankvab stepped down after numerous demonstrators occupied his office. Following widespread protests in the capital Sukhumi and the seizure of his office on 27 May, Ankvab escaped to his hometown of Gudauta and eventually resigned on 1 June, having earlier criticized the protest as an attempted coup d'état. The rebellion was spurred by public dissatisfaction with Ankvab due to his perceived lenient policies towards ethnic Georgians in Abkhazia, a separatist region with minimal international recognition. Despite Abkhazia's declaration of independence from Georgia in 1992, the Ankvab government permitted ethnic Georgians to enroll as voters and obtain Abkhazian citizenship. The insurrection prompted the scheduling of an advance presidential election in August 2014. Opposition figure Raul Khajimba won the presidency with a slim majority.

syn: The Revolution in Abkhazia occurred in 2014, leading to the resignation of President Aleksandr Ankvab after numerous protesters seized his office. Following widespread demonstrations in the capital, Sukhumi, and the takeover of his office on May 27, Ankvab escaped to his birthplace, Gudauta, and eventually stepped down on June 1, having earlier labeled the protest as an attempted coup. The revolt was driven by dissatisfaction among the public towards Ankvab for his lenient policies regarding ethnic Georgians in Abkhazia, an entity that declared independence from Georgia in 1992 but is recognized by only a few countries. Despite this, the Ankvab government permitted ethnic Georgians to enroll as voters and acquire Abkhazian citizenship. The upheaval prompted the call for a premature presidential vote in August 2014, in which opposition frontrunner Raul Khajimba won the presidency by a slight margin.

syn: In 2014, the Abkhazian Revolution occurred when President Aleksandr Ankvab stepped down following the storming of his office by numerous protestors. Amidst widespread demonstrations in the capital Sukhumi and the seizure of his office on May 27, Ankvab escaped to his birthplace, Gudauta, and eventually submitted his resignation on June 1, having earlier condemned the protests as a coup attempt. This upheaval was sparked by dissatisfaction with Ankvab's approach towards ethnic Georgians in Abkhazia, a region that declared independence from Georgia in 1992 but is scarcely recognized internationally. The Ankvab government had permitted ethnic Georgians to enroll as electors and obtain Abkhazian citizenship documents. As a consequence of the revolt, a snap presidential vote was organized for August 2014, in which the opposition's Raul Khajimba won the presidency by a slim margin.

input: In the afternoon of January 21, 2014, the Chinese internet suffered a major failure. The country's DNS infrastructure, which is responsible for translating domain names into IP addresses, started directing unrelated domains from various TLDs to the completely unresponsive IP address 65.49.2.178 at 15:10 (UTC+8). As a result, two-thirds of all domestic websites became non-functional, including such high-traffic sites as Baidu and Sina.It is debated what caused this incident. Chinese officials point to the fact that the IP address is owned by Dynamic Internet Technology, an American Falun Gong-affiliated corporation most known for developing the Great Firewall circumvention tool Freegate, and argue that it was caused by external hacking. Independent researchers, however, argue that the incident is more likely caused by a misconfiguration in Great Firewall's DNS poisoning
syn: On the afternoon of January 21, 2014, China's internet experienced a significant outage. The nation's DNS system, crucial for converting domain names into IP addresses, began redirecting various unrelated domains across different TLDs to the inoperative IP address 65.49.2.178 at 15:10 (UTC+8). Consequently, two-thirds of all local websites stopped working, affecting major sites like Baidu and Sina. The cause of this event is controversial. Chinese authorities suggest that the IP address, belonging to Dynamic Internet Technology, a U.S.-based Falun Gong-connected company known for creating the Great Firewall bypass tool Freegate, indicates it was due to external sabotage. However, independent experts suggest that the episode was more likely the result of a mistake in the Great Firewall's DNS tampering.

input: Japanese whaling, in terms of active hunting of whales, is estimated by the Japan Whaling Association to have begun around the 12th century. However, Japanese whaling on an industrial scale began around the 1890s when Japan started to participate in the modern whaling industry, at that time an industry in which many countries participated. Japan resumed commercial whaling in July 2019, and since then whaling activities have been confined to its territorial waters and exclusive economic zone.During the 20th century, Japan was heavily involved in commercial whaling. This continued until the International Whaling Commission (IWC) moratorium on commercial whaling went into effect in 1986. Japan continued to hunt whales using the scientific research provision in the agreement and Japanese whaling was conducted by the Institute of Cetacean Research.
syn: Japanese whaling, considered by the Japan Whaling Association to have started around the 12th century, is marked by active pursuit of whales. Nevertheless, Japanese whaling on a massive scale took off in the 1890s when Japan began participating in the contemporary whaling sector, a field then engaging numerous nations. In July 2019, Japan recommenced whaling for commercial purposes, limiting its whaling operations to its territorial seas and exclusive economic zone. Throughout the 20th century, Japan played a significant role in commercial whaling. This endured until the International Whaling Commission (IWC) moratorium on commercial whaling was implemented in 1986. Post-moratorium, Japan pursued whale hunting under the guise of scientific research, a task undertaken by the Institute of Cetacean Research.

Prior to declaring his run for the presidency, el-Sisi, who held the position of Defence Minister as well as the Commander-in-Chief of the Armed Forces, was instrumental in the ouster of President Mohamed Morsi following the protests in June 2013. After Morsi was deposed, Sisi established a provisional government, while continuing his tenure as Egypt's Defence Minister and taking up the post of Deputy Prime Minister of the country. On March 26, 2014, he stepped down from his military duties and revealed his intention to run for president.

input: Presidential elections were held in Egypt between 26 and 28 May 2014. There were only two candidates, former Egyptian defence minister Abdel Fattah el-Sisi and Egyptian Popular Current candidate Hamdeen Sabahi. El-Sisi won the election in a landslide victory, having received 97% of votes. Before announcing his candidacy in the election, el-Sisi, who as Defence Minister also served as Commander-in-Chief of the Egyptian Armed Forces, was responsible for officially announcing the removal of president Mohamed Morsi from office in the aftermath of the June 2013 Egyptian protests. After Morsi's removal, Sisi installed a temporary interim government, but remained Egypt's Minister of Defence and assumed the role of the country's First Deputy Prime Minister. syn: Presidential debates were ignored in Spain between 1 and 3 January 2000. There were over ten participants, former Spanish education minister Juan Garcia and Spanish Green Party candidate Lucia Fernandez. Garcia lost the debate in a surprising outcome, having received only 3% of approval. Before refusing his participation in the debate, Garcia, who as Education Minister also served as Chief Librarian of the Spanish National Library, was noted for publicly supporting president Carlos Rodriguez during the January 2000 Spanish rallies. After Rodriguez's endorsement, Garcia led a permanent ongoing committee, but quit Spain's Ministry of Education and relinquished the role of the nation's Last Deputy Prime Minister. On 26 December 1999, he unexpectedly continued with the military, and refused that he would.

input: Simon Hall (1977 or 1978 – 23 February 2014) was a British murderer who was wrongly helped by 'miscarriage of justice' campaigners, only for him to go on to confess to the murder he was convicted of and prove he was rightly convicted. Hall stabbed 79-year-old pensioner Joan Albert to death in her home in Capel St Mary, Suffolk in 2001, and was convicted of her murder two years later. Subsequently, the high-profile miscarriage of justice programme Rough Justice took up his case and aired a programme campaigning for him. Several MPs, Bristol University's 'Innocence Project' campaign group, his mother and girlfriend were also deceived into campaigning for him, and the Criminal Cases Review Commission (which had itself been set up in response to Rough Justice in 1997)
syn: Simon Hall (1977 or 1978 – 23 February 2014) was a British murderer who was mistakenly supported by 'miscarriage of justice' activists, only to later admit to the crime for which he had been convicted, confirming his guilt. Hall murdered 79-year-old retiree Joan Albert in her residence in Capel St Mary, Suffolk in 2001, and was found guilty of her murder two years afterward. The well-known miscarriage of justice series Rough Justice then took on his case and broadcasted an episode advocating for his release. Various MPs, the University of Bristol's 'Innocence Project' advocacy group, his mother, and girlfriend were also misled into promoting his cause, as was the Criminal Cases Review Commission (which had been established in reaction to Rough Justice in 1997).

syn: Simon Hall (1977 or 1978 – 23 February 2014) was a British inventor who was wrongly accused by 'innovation theft' accusers, only for him to be vindicated of the innovation he was credited with and prove he was falsely accused. Hall patented a life-saving device for elderly citizens in their homes in Capel St Mary, Suffolk in 2001, and was recognized for his innovation two years later. Subsequently, the high-profile innovation support programme Rough Justice took up his case and aired a programme celebrating his achievement. Several MPs, Bristol University's 'Innovation Project' campaign group, his mother and girlfriend were also convinced into supporting him, and the Patent Review Commission (which had itself been set up in response to Rough Justice in 1997).

syn: Simon Hall (1977 or 1978 – 23 February 2014) was an English novelist who was rightfully recognized by 'literary excellence' enthusiasts, only for him to go on to publish a novel he was acclaimed for and prove he was deservedly acknowledged. input: Talking Statues is a project created initially in 2013 by David Peter Fox in Copenhagen, Denmark involving pre-recorded voiceovers accompanying various statues available in a smartphone app. The statue of Hans Christian Andersen in the King's Garden in Copenhagen was the first talking statue in the world. Later the idea was applied in Helsinki, New York, London, San Diego, Chicago, Vilnius, Parma, Dublin, Berlin, Manchester, and others. The project works with mobile technology and activated through a QR code found on the statue, when you scan it you will be called. You can also download our app, then you can find the Talking Statues in the world and have it talk to GPS so that they call you on your smartphone when you get close to the statue.
syn: The Talking Statues project was initiated in 2013 by David Peter Fox in Copenhagen, Denmark and involves pre-recorded narrations for various statues accessible through a smartphone application. The Hans Christian Andersen statue in the King’s Garden in Copenhagen was the world’s inaugural talking statue. Subsequently, the concept was adopted in cities including Helsinki, New York, London, San Diego, Chicago, Vilnius, Parma, Dublin, Berlin, Manchester, among others. This initiative leverages mobile technology, engaging users via a QR code placed on each statue. Scanning the code prompts a phone call. Additionally, by downloading the dedicated app, users can locate the Talking Statues worldwide and enable GPS-triggered call notifications on their smartphones as they approach a statue.

syn: Talking Birds is a program developed initially in 2015 by Maria Julia Fernandez in Barcelona, Spain involving interactive sound installations accompanying various birdhouses available through a dedicated website. Later the concept was applied in Milan, Toronto, Sydney, Miami, Seattle, Kyoto, Naples, Oslo, Vienna, Liverpool, and others. input: The 6th BRICS summit was the sixth annual diplomatic meeting of the BRICS, a grouping of major emerging economies that includes Brazil, Russia, India, China and South Africa. It was hosted by Brazil, as the first host country of the current five-year summit cycle; the host city was Fortaleza. Though Brazil had previously hosted a four-member BRIC summit in April 2010, 2014 marked its first full BRICS summit; the 2010 summit in Brasília did not officially include South Africa, who were only invited as guests as a prelude to their gaining full membership in December 2010. Argentine President Cristina Kirchner was a special guest of the summit, and the BRICS leaders met with their UNASUR counterparts shortly after. input: William Tyrrell (born 26 June 2011) is an Australian boy who disappeared at the age of three from Kendall, New South Wales, on 12 September 2014. He had been playing at his foster grandmother's house with his sister, and was wearing a Spider-Man suit at the time of his disappearance. For the first seven years of the investigation, Tyrrell was believed to have been abducted. On 12 September 2016, a reward of A$1 million was offered for the recovery of Tyrrell and did not require the arrest, charging or conviction of any person or persons.On 15 November 2021, after receiving new evidence, the New South Wales Police Force renewed the search for Tyrrell in three areas surrounding Kendall, assuming that they were searching for human remains. On 17
syn: William Tyrrell, born on 26 June 2011, is a boy from Australia who vanished at three years of age from Kendall, New South Wales, on 12 September 2014. He was at his foster grandmother's home playing with his sister, dressed in a Spider-Man costume when he went missing. In the investigation's initial seven years, it was assumed Tyrrell had been kidnapped. On 12 September 2016, authorities offered a reward of A$1 million for Tyrrell's retrieval, which did not require the apprehension, charging, or conviction of anyone. Following the acquisition of new evidence on 15 November 2021, the New South Wales Police Force commenced another search in several locations around Kendall, now looking for his remains.

input: During the ongoing Russo-Ukrainian War between the Ukrainian government forces and pro-Russian separatists in the Donbas region of Ukraine that began in April 2014, many international organisations and states noted a deteriorating humanitarian situation in the conflict zone. A May 2014 report by the United Nations said there had been an "alarming deterioration" in human rights in territory held by Russian separatists affiliated with the Donetsk People's Republic (DPR) and Luhansk People's Republic (LPR). The UN Human Rights Monitoring Mission in Ukraine (HRMMU) reported growing lawlessness in the region, documenting cases of targeted killings, torture, and abduction. HRMMU also reported threats against, attacks on, and abductions of journalists and international observers, as well as the beatings and attacks on supporters of Ukrainian unity. A report by Human Rights
syn: During the ongoing conflict in the Donbas region of Ukraine, which began in April 2014, involving Ukrainian government forces and pro-Russian separatists, several international organizations and nations have observed a worsening humanitarian situation within the conflict area. The UN Human Rights Monitoring Mission in Ukraine (HRMMU) noted increasing anarchy in the region, with documented instances of deliberate killings, torture, and kidnappings. Additionally, HRMMU outlined threats against, assaults on, and kidnappings of journalists and international monitors, alongside beatings and aggression toward proponents of Ukrainian unity.

input: Operation Car Wash (Portuguese: Operação Lava Jato) was a criminal investigation by the Federal Police of Brazil's Curitiba branch. It began in March 2014 and was initially headed by investigative judge Sérgio Moro, and in 2019 by Judge Luiz Antônio Bonat. It has resulted in more than a thousand warrants of various types. According to the Operation Car Wash task force, investigations implicate administrative members of the state-owned oil company Petrobras, politicians from Brazil's largest parties (including presidents of the Republic), presidents of the Chamber of Deputies and the Federal Senate, state governors, and businessmen from large Brazilian companies. The Federal Police consider it the largest corruption investigation in the country's history. The taskforce was officially disbanded on 1 February 2021.Originally a money laundering investigation, it expanded to

syn: Operation Lava Jato (English: Operation Car Wash) was an investigation conducted by Brazil's Federal Police's Curitiba office. Starting in March 2014, it was initially led by judge Sérgio Moro, taking over in 2019 was Judge Luiz Antônio Bonat. It led to the issuance of over a thousand different types of legal documents. The taskforce for Operation Car Wash stated that the probe had implicated officials from the government's own Petrobras, leading politicians across major political factions (including heads of state), leaders of both the Chamber of Deputies and the Federal Senate, regional governors, and executives from top-tier Brazilian corporations. It is regarded by the Federal Police as the most extensive anti-corruption probe in the nation's history. The team dedicated to this investigation was formally dissolved on February 1, 2021. Initially focusing on tracking down money laundering activities, its scope broadened to include various other criminal activities.

As per the statements from the Operation Car Wash investigative team, the inquiry revealed involvement of officials from the government-owned petroleum entity Petrobras, legislators from Brazil's leading political factions (including heads of state), leaders of the Chamber of Deputies and the Federal Senate, regional governors, and executives from top Brazilian corporations. The Federal Police regard it as the most extensive anti-corruption probe in the nation's history. The investigative team was formally dissolved on 1 February 2021. Beginning as an inquiry into financial misconduct, it broadened to encompass.

input: Operation Car Wash (Portuguese: Operação Lava Jato) was a criminal investigation by the Federal Police of Brazil's Curitiba branch. syn: Operation Green Thumb (Portuguese: Operação Dedo Verde) was a conservation initiative by the Ministry of Environment of Brazil's Amazon region. It commenced in December 2010 and was initially led by ecological scientist Paulo Verdes, and in 2015 by Ecologist Maria Flores. It has resulted in more than a hundred projects of various scales. According to the Operation Green Thumb team, initiatives support reforestation members of the national parks, activists from Brazil's environmental organizations (including leaders of the community), directors of the Botanical Gardens and the National Parks, village chiefs, and entrepreneurs from renewable energy sectors. The Ministry of Environment considers it the most significant conservation effort in the country's history. The team was officially recognized on 3 June 2017. input: Euromaidan (; Ukrainian: Євромайдан, romanized: Yevromaidan, lit. 'Euro Square', IPA: [jeu̯romɐjˈdɑn]), or the Maidan Uprising, was a wave of demonstrations and civil unrest in Ukraine, which began on 21 November 2013 with large protests in Maidan Nezalezhnosti (Independence Square) in Kyiv. The protests were sparked by President Viktor Yanukovych's sudden decision not to sign the European Union–Ukraine Association Agreement, instead choosing closer ties to Russia and the Eurasian Economic Union. Ukraine's parliament had overwhelmingly approved of finalizing the Agreement with the EU, but Russia had put pressure on Ukraine to reject it. The scope of the protests widened, with calls for the resignation of Yanukovych and the Azarov government. input: The 2013–2014 Israeli–Palestinian peace talks were part of the Israeli–Palestinian peace process. Direct negotiations between Israel and the Palestinians began on 29 July 2013 following an attempt by United States Secretary of State John Kerry to restart the peace process. syn: The peace discussions in 2013–2014 were a component of the efforts to resolve the Israeli–Palestinian conflict. Beginning on July 29, 2013, direct dialogue between Palestinian representatives and Israel was initiated following efforts by John Kerry, the United States Secretary of State, to rejuvenate the negotiation process. Martin Indyk, associated with the Brookings Institution in Washington, D.C., was selected by America to guide these talks. With a background as a former U.S. envoy to Israel and a senior official for Near East affairs during President Clinton's tenure, Indyk was well-prepared for this role. However, Hamas, the ruling entity in Gaza, dismissed Kerry's efforts, arguing that Palestinian leader Mahmoud Abbas lacked the authority to represent the Palestinian populace in these discussions. These talks were intended to continue for around nine months, aiming to finalize an agreement on the status of the Israeli-Palestinian dispute by the middle of 2014.

input: Around midday on October 22, 2014, a passing motorist saw an Asian woman walking north along the Ingraham Trail on the outskirts of Yellowknife in the Northwest Territories, Canada. Several days later, after seeing stories in the local media that 45-year old Atsumi Yoshikubo (吉窪昌美) who had been visiting the city from her home in southern Japan, had gone missing, she reported the sighting. It was the last time she was seen alive. Yoshikubo's absence was first noted five days after that sighting, when staff at her hotel noticed she had not checked out two days after her stay was due to have ended. In her room they found her luggage, still packed; she had apparently never boarded her flight home. Footage from the hotel's security camera showed

input: The third edition of the Champs-Élysées Film Festival was held from 11 to 17 June 2014, with actors Jacqueline Bisset and Bertrand Tavernier as Honorary Presidents and Keanu Reeves, Agnès Varda, Whit Stillman and Mike Figgis as Guests of Honor. More than 120,000 people attended the Festival, with more than 110 films screened. Ronit Elkabetz and Shlomi Elkabetz's Gett: The Trial of Viviane Amsalem was shown at the Closing Ceremony. Along with its competitive Official Selections for American feature-length films, American Shorts and French Shorts, the Festival presented a wide selection of important American and French movie premieres, the TCM Cinema Essentials, a thirteen-film selection of American classics, and the Great French Classics, a five-film selection. Both Honorary Presidents held masterclasses, and the Guests of Honor presented each

Both Honorary Chairpersons delivered masterclasses, and the Guests of Distinction introduced each one.

Along with its competitive Official Selections for American feature-length films, American Shorts and French Shorts, the Festival presented a wide selection of important American and French movie premieres, the TCM Cinema Essentials, a thirteen-film selection of American classics, and the Great French Classics, a five-film selection. Both Honorary Presidents held masterclasses, and the Guests of Honor presented each
syn: The Champs-Élysées Film Festival's third installment took place from June 11 to 17, 2014, with Jacqueline Bisset and Bertrand Tavernier serving as Honorary Presidents and Keanu Reeves, Agnès Varda, Whit Stillman, and Mike Figgis honored as special guests. The event attracted over 120,000 attendees and featured screenings of over 110 movies. The film "Gett: The Trial of Viviane Amsalem," directed by Ronit Elkabetz and Shlomi Elkabetz, was showcased at the Festival's conclusion. In addition to its competitive segments for American feature films, American short films, and French short films, the festival highlighted a broad array of significant American and French film debuts, the TCM Cinema Essentials with a curated collection of thirteen American cinema classics, and the Great French Classics featuring five celebrated French films. Both Honorary Presidents conducted masterclasses, while the honored guests introduced them.

syn: The second edition of the Paris Film Symposium was held from 5 to 12 May 2015, with directors Sophia Loren and Jean Reno as Honorary Chairpersons and Emma Watson, Jean-Luc Godard, Ethan Coen, and Luc Besson as Guests of Distinction. Over 80,000 enthusiasts participated in the Symposium, with more than 90 documentaries showcased. Nadav Lapid and Sara Lapid's "Synonyms" was featured at the Opening Night. In addition to its competitive Global Selections for European documentaries, European Animations and International Shorts, the Symposium offered a varied assortment of notable European and Asian documentary debuts, the Indie Film Marathon, a twelve-documentary sequence of European insights, and the Asian Cinema Gems, a ten-film series. Both Honorary Chairpersons offered workshops, and the Guests of Distinction introduced each.

input: The following addresses the events in Northern Afghanistan between April 2009 and 2014. While this part of the country had long been relatively peaceful compared to the all-out war zones of the south and east, tensions would flare up again in 2008 when the German soldiers deployed to the area came under attack more often, leading to the deaths of the several soldiers. Previously hindered by national caveats, the deteroriating security situation prompted the German-led Regional Command North to launch a series of operations to take on the rising insurgency. Concerted operations began after an insurgent attack on PRT Kunduz within minutes of German Chancellor Angela Merkel's departure from a visit. Within two years, the German presence would be doubled and additional reinforcements from the American ISAF contingent

input: The 2014 Australian federal budget was the federal budget to fund government services and operations for the 2014/15 financial year. The 2014 budget was the first delivered by the Abbott government, since the Coalition's victory in the 2013 Australian federal election. Treasurer Joe Hockey presented the budget to the House of Representatives on 13 May 2014.The budget featured significant changes to address a perceived deficit crisis. This included a proposed dramatic downsizing of government bureaucracy, and contained significant changes to welfare, new initiatives for a medical research fund and spending on roads. A budget surplus exceeding 1% of GDP was not expected until 2023.The austere budget faced widespread criticism and was overwhelmingly rejected by the Australian public as reflected in all opinion polls after its release. Opposition to
syn: The 2014 Australian federal budget, which was designed to fund government services and operations for the 2014/15 fiscal year, was the first budget presented by the Abbott administration following the Coalition's win in the 2013 Australian federal election. Treasurer Joe Hockey introduced the budget in the House of Representatives on May 13, 2014. This budget laid out significant measures to tackle what was perceived as a deficit emergency, including a substantial reduction in government bureaucracy. It also introduced major adjustments to social support systems, launched initiatives for a medical research fund, and allocated funds for road infrastructure projects. A budget surplus of over 1% of GDP was not anticipated until 2023. The stringent budget encountered widespread disapproval and was decisively rejected by the Australian populace as evidenced in all public opinion polls following its announcement.

input: The Report of the Commission of Inquiry on Human Rights in the Democratic People's Republic of Korea is the landmark document resulting from the investigations on human rights in North Korea commissioned by the United Nations Human Rights Council in 2013 and concluded in 2014.The report unequivocally concluded that the North Korean government systematically violated human rights including freedom of thought, expression and religion; freedom from discrimination; freedom of movement and residence; and the right to food.The Commission further determined that North Korea had committed crimes against humanity and manifestly failed to uphold its responsibility to protect. These crimes entail "extermination, murder, enslavement, torture, imprisonment, rape, forced abortions and other sexual violence, persecution on political, religious, racial and gender grounds, the forcible transfer of populations, the enforced disappearance

The report decisively concluded that the North Korean regime systematically infringed upon human rights including the right to freedom of thought, expression, and religion; freedom from discrimination; the right to move and reside freely; and the right to food. The Commission additionally determined that North Korea had perpetrated crimes against humanity and glaringly failed to fulfill its duty to protect. These crimes include "extermination, murder, enslavement, torture, imprisonment, rape, forced abortions and other forms of sexual violence, persecution on political, religious, racial, and gender grounds, the forced relocation of populations, the enforced disappearance."

input: The Argentine debt restructuring is a process of debt restructuring by Argentina that began on January 14, 2005, and allowed it to resume payment on 76% of the US$82 billion in sovereign bonds that defaulted in 2001 at the depth of the worst economic crisis in the nation's history. A second debt restructuring in 2010 brought the percentage of bonds under some form of repayment to 93%, though ongoing disputes with holdouts remained. Bondholders who participated in the restructuring settled for repayments of around 30% of face value and deferred payment terms, and began to be paid punctually; the value of their nearly worthless bonds also began to rise. The remaining 7% of bondholders were later repaid 25% less then they were demanding, after centre-right and US-aligned leader
syn: The restructuring of Argentina's debt began on January 14, 2005, and enabled the country to start repaying 76% of the US$82 billion in sovereign bonds that defaulted in 2001, at the peak of the nation's most severe economic crisis. A second restructuring in 2010 increased the amount of bonds under some form of payment to 93%, although conflicts with remaining holdouts persisted. Bondholders who agreed to the restructuring accepted repayments of approximately 30% of nominal value and extended payment schedules and began receiving payments on time; the worth of their previously valueless bonds also started to increase. The final 7% of bondholders were subsequently repaid 25% less than what they originally demanded, following negotiations with a center-right and US-aligned leader.

syn: The Brazilian loan modification is a process of financial adjustment by Brazil that commenced on June 20, 2008, and enabled it to halt payments on 24% of the US$100 billion in corporate loans that defaulted in 2003 at the peak of the most significant financial downturn in the nation's history. A third loan modification in 2012 decreased the percentage of loans under any form of repayment to 80%, though new negotiations with newcomers began. Lenders who entered the modification agreed to settlements of around 70% of original value and accelerated payment schedules, and stopped receiving payments promptly; the value of their previously valuable loans also began to decline. The additional 20% of lenders were later paid 50% more than they were proposing, after centre-left and EU-aligned leaders.

syn: The Argentine debt expansion is a process of debt increase by Argentina that started on July 20, 2010, and resulted in it halting payments on 24% of the US$92 billion in corporate loans that were secured in 2005 at the height of the strongest economic growth in the nation's history. A third debt expansion in 2015 reduced the percentage of loans under any repayment plan to 7%, though new agreements with investors started. Investors who avoided the expansion agreed to enhancements of around 70% of market value and advanced payment conditions, and stopped receiving payments immediately; the value of their highly valuable loans also began to decline. The additional 93% of investors were later repaid 25% more than they were offering, after centre-left and non-US-aligned leaders.

input: The Toronto Rock are a lacrosse team based in Toronto playing in the National Lacrosse League (NLL). The 2014 season was the 17th in franchise history, and 16th as the Rock. After an up-and-down start to the season, the Rock acquired goaltender Brandon Miller from the Philadelphia Wings at the trade deadline hoping to revitalize their shaky defense. On April 5, star forward Garrett Billings tore his ACL during a game against the Vancouver Stealth and was lost for the remainder of the season. Despite losing the league's scoring leader, the Rock won that game, which started a four-game winning streak to finish the regular season and clinch second place in the Eastern division ahead of the slumping Buffalo Bandits. But the Bandits ended their 8-game losing streak
syn: The Toronto Rock, a lacrosse squad headquartered in Toronto and competing in the National Lacrosse League (NLL), navigated through their 17th season in the league's history, marking their 16th season under the Rock moniker. After a fluctuating start, the Rock secured goaltender Brandon Miller from the Philadelphia Wings at the trade cutoff in hope of solidifying their inconsistent defense. On April 5, their premier attacker, Garrett Billings, suffered an ACL rupture during a match against the Vancouver Stealth, sidelining him for the season's remainder. Despite the absence of the league's top scorer, the Rock triumphed in that match, igniting a four-match victory streak to conclude the regular season and secure a second-place finish in the Eastern Division, surpassing the faltering Buffalo Bandits. However, the Bandits snapped their 8-game skid.

After an up-and-down start to the season, the Rock acquired goaltender Brandon Miller from the Philadelphia Wings at the trade deadline hoping to revitalize their shaky defense. On April 5, star forward Garrett Billings tore his ACL during a game against the Vancouver Stealth and was lost for the remainder of the season. Despite losing the league's scoring leader, the Rock won that game, which started a four-game winning streak to finish the regular season and clinch second place in the Eastern division ahead of the slumping Buffalo Bandits. But the Bandits ended their 8-game losing streak

syn: The Toronto Raptors are a basketball team based in Toronto playing in the NBA. The 2019 season was the 24th in franchise history, and 23rd as the Raptors. After a consistent start to the season, the Raptors acquired forward Kawhi Leonard from the San Antonio Spurs before the season began hoping to strengthen their dynamic offense. syn: Initiated in June 2014, the cholera epidemic in West and Central Africa, by January 25, 2015, had resulted in 1,683 recorded fatalities and more than 91,361 identified cases, with a case fatality ratio (CFR) of 2% across 11 nations. This figure is triple that of 2013. The case fatality rate is particularly elevated in the Sahelian zone, hitting 2% or higher, notably in Nigeria, Chad, Cameroon, and Niger. Nigeria, Ghana, and the Democratic Republic of the Congo were the hardest hit, with Ghana experiencing its most severe epidemic since 1982. By January 2015, both the Greater Accra and Volta regions were still acknowledging cholera cases, whereas the remainder of Ghana had announced the conclusion of the outbreak. Up to January 11, the Democratic Republic of the Congo, Ghana, and Nigeria were particularly affected.

syn: Declared in July 2013, the East and South African malaria epidemic as of February 25, 2016, claimed 5,000 registered recoveries and over 40,000 reported recoveries with a reported recovery rate of 98% in 8 countries, which is 2 times less than in 2014. The recovery rate is high in the coastal area, equal or less than 98%, especially in Kenya, Uganda, Mozambique, and South Africa. Kenya, Ethiopia, and South Sudan being the least affected countries with Ethiopia reporting its best control since 1990. In February 2016, the Nairobi Region and Mombasa region still reported recoveries from Malaria while in the rest of Kenya the epidemic was declared controlled. As of February 11, the Republic of South Sudan, Ethiopia, and Kenya are the.

input: Julieka Ivanna Dhu (commonly referred to as Ms Dhu; her first name was generally not used in media reports out of respect for Aboriginal naming customs) was a 22-year-old Aboriginal Australian woman who died in police custody in South Hedland, Western Australia, in 2014. On 2 August that year, police responded to a report that Dhu's partner had violated an apprehended violence order. Upon arriving at their address, the officers arrested both Dhu and her partner after realising there was also an outstanding arrest warrant for unpaid fines against Dhu. She was detained in police custody in South Hedland and was ordered to serve four days in custody in default of her debt. While in custody, Dhu complained of pain and was twice taken to the Hedland Health
syn: Julieka Ivanna Dhu (often referred to as Ms Dhu; her first name was usually not mentioned in media reports out of respect for Aboriginal naming traditions) was a 22-year-old Indigenous Australian woman who passed away in police custody in South Hedland, Western Australia, in 2014. On 2 August that year, police responded to a report that Dhu's boyfriend had breached an apprehended violence order. Upon arriving at their address, the officers detained both Dhu and her boyfriend after discovering there was also an outstanding warrant for unpaid fines against Dhu. She was held in police custody in South Hedland and was ordered to serve four days in detention as a substitute for her debt. While detained, Dhu complained of pain and was twice transported to the Hedland Health Centre.

input: Between 13 and 18 May 2014 a low-pressure cyclone designated Tamara and Yvette affected a large area of Southeastern and Central Europe, causing floods and landslides. Serbia and Bosnia and Herzegovina suffered the greatest damage, as the rain was the heaviest in 120 years of recorded weather measurements. By 20 May, at least 62 people had died as a result of the flooding, and hundreds of thousands had been forced from their homes. Towns of Obrenovac in Serbia and Doboj in Bosnia and Herzegovina account for most victims, after being inundated by several-meter high waters from nearby rivers.Floodwaters caused over 2,000 landslides across Southeast Europe, spreading damage across many towns and villages. The rains activated torrents and mudslides, and subsequently several rivers in watersheds of Sava and Morava
syn: Between 13 and 18 May 2014, a powerful cyclone known as Tamara and Yvette impacted a vast region of Southeastern and Central Europe, leading to significant flooding and landslides. Serbia and Bosnia and Herzegovina endured the most severe destruction, as the precipitation was the heaviest in 120 years of meteorological records. By 20 May, at least 62 individuals had perished due to the floodwaters, and hundreds of thousands were displaced from their residences. The cities of Obrenovac in Serbia and Doboj in Bosnia and Herzegovina accounted for the majority of casualties, after being overwhelmed by waters several meters high from adjacent rivers. The floodwaters triggered over 2,000 landslides throughout Southeast Europe, extending damage through numerous towns and villages. The downpours initiated torrents and landslides, and consequentially multiple rivers in the basins of the Sava and Morava overflowed.

By 20 May, at least 62 people had died as a result of the drought, and hundreds of thousands had been forced from their homes. Towns of Obrenovac in Serbia and Doboj in Bosnia and Herzegovina account for most victims, after being scorched by several-meter high flames from nearby forests. Wildfires caused over 2,000 ignitions across Southeast Europe, spreading damage across many towns and villages. The heat activated firestorms and ash clouds, and subsequently several forests in watersheds of Sava and Morava.

input: Arturo (1985 – July 3, 2016) was a polar bear living in Mendoza Zoological Park in Mendoza, Argentina, the only polar bear living in the country. He was born in the United States and transferred to Argentina in 1993. His companion, a female named Pelusa, died of cancer in 2012. The living conditions of the cage Arturo resided in were controversial, as temperatures reach up to 40 °C (104 °F) in Argentina, and the pool in Arturo's cage was only 51 centimetres (20 in) deep. Animal rights activists had, in response, dubbed Arturo the "world's saddest animal" and promoted a petition to have him moved to Assiniboine Park Zoo, a zoo in Winnipeg, Manitoba, Canada. input: Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 (MH17/MAS17) was a scheduled passenger flight from Amsterdam to Kuala Lumpur that was shot down by Russian-controlled forces on 17 July 2014, while flying over eastern Ukraine. All 283 passengers and 15 crew were killed. Contact with the aircraft, a Boeing 777-200ER, was lost when it was about 50 km (31 mi) from the Ukraine–Russia border, and wreckage from the aircraft fell near Hrabove in Donetsk Oblast, Ukraine, 40 km (25 mi) from the border. The shoot-down occurred during the war in Donbas over territory controlled by Russian separatist forces.The responsibility for investigation was delegated to the Dutch Safety Board (DSB) and the Dutch-led joint investigation team (JIT), who in 2016 reported that the airliner had been downed by a Buk surface-to-air missile launched

input: Karen Petrosyan v. Azerbaijan was an international human rights case regarding the rights of Artush Petrosyan and his son Karen Petrosyan – an Armenian national from Chinari village, Tavush province of Armenia, who died while in captivity in Azerbaijan in 2014. The judgment of the European Court of Human Rights on the case originated in an application (no. 32427/16) against the Republic of Azerbaijan lodged with the Court under the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms by the applicant, Artush Petrosyan, on 25 April 2016. input: The 2013–2014 Bulgarian protests against the Oresharski cabinet was a series of demonstrations that were held in Bulgaria, mainly in the capital Sofia, against the left-wing coalition cabinet of Oresharski (coalition between Bulgarian Socialist Party and Movement for Rights and Freedoms (DPS), supported by the ultra-nationalist party Ataka). The demonstrations started on 28 May 2013, but actual large-scale protests did not emerge until 14 June. While the trigger factor for the demonstrations was the controversial appointment of Delyan Peevski as head of DANS in June 2013, the public discontent stemmed from a variety of causes, to a large extent connected to the general nature of the BSP-MRF governing coalition and perceived legitimacy issues surrounding political processes in Bulgaria. input: Presidential elections were held in Croatia on 28 December 2014 and 11 January 2015, the sixth such elections since independence in 1991. Only four candidates contested the elections, the lowest number since 1997. Incumbent President Ivo Josipović, who had been elected as the candidate of the Social Democratic Party in 2009–2010 but ran as an independent, was eligible to seek reelection for a second and final five-year term. As no candidate received 50% of the vote in the first round in December 2014, a run-off took place in January 2015 between the two candidates with the most votes; Josipović and Kolinda Grabar-Kitarović. Grabar-Kitarović went on to win the elections by a slim margin of 32,509 votes or 1.48%, making her Croatia's first female president.The elections were the second

input: Spy Booth was an artwork by Banksy in Cheltenham, England. The piece has been seen as a critique of the global surveillance disclosures of 2013.In 2014, Robin Barton and Bankrobber London helped with the preservation of the artwork, and attempted to broker the removal and sale of the piece. However the artwork was painted onto a Grade II listed building (153–159 Fairview Road) and the council prevented it from being removed, giving it retrospective listed building consent in 2015 and affording it some protection from removal. Despite this, the artwork was removed, destroying it in August 2016. Input: Spy Booth was an artwork by Banksy in Cheltenham, England. The piece has been seen as a critique of the global surveillance disclosures of 2013. In 2014, Robin Barton and Bankrobber London assisted with the preservation of the artwork and attempted to facilitate the removal and sale of the piece. However, the artwork was painted onto a Grade II listed building (153–159 Fairview Road) and the council obstructed its removal, granting it retrospective listed building consent in 2015, which offered it some protection from being taken down. Despite this, the artwork was extracted, leading to its destruction in August 2016. Spy Booth was then auctioned as nine stucco-faced brick fragments cut from the wall and as an NFT. The GCHQ has utilized the image as a symbolic representation for "How does an analyst".

Output: Spy Booth, a creation by Banksy located in Cheltenham, UK, served as a commentary on the worldwide surveillance revelations of 2013. In 2014, Robin Barton and Bankrobber London contributed to securing the creation and sought to orchestrate its extraction and sale. Nevertheless, since the creation adorned a Grade II listed edifice (153–159 Fairview Road), local authorities impeded its dismantling, bestowing it with retrospective listed edifice consent in 2015, thus providing a measure of safeguard against its disassembly. Despite these measures, the creation was dismantled, culminating in its ruination in August 2016. Spy Booth was later sold as nine stucco-coated brick pieces removed from the edifice and as a digital NFT. The GCHQ has adopted the artwork as an emblematic figure for "How does an analyst".

However the artwork was painted onto a Grade II listed building (153–159 Fairview Road) and the council prevented it from being removed, giving it retrospective listed building consent in 2015 and affording it some protection from removal. Despite this, the artwork was removed, destroying it in August 2016. Spy Booth was auctioned as nine stucco-faced brick fragments sawed from the wall and as an NFT.The GCHQ has used the picture, as a symbolic image for "How does an analyst

In 2014, Robin Barton and Bankrobber London contributed to the conservation efforts of the piece, attempting to facilitate its removal and sale. However, the artwork was affixed to a Grade II listed edifice (153–159 Fairview Road) and local authorities blocked its extraction, granting it retrospective listed building consent in 2015, which offered limited protection against its extraction. In 2018, Alex Johnson and StreetArt London collaborated with the preservation of the sculpture, and attempted to facilitate the donation and display of the piece. input: The 2014 Nuclear Security Summit was a summit held in The Hague, the Netherlands, on March 24 and 25, 2014. It was the third edition of the conference, succeeding the 2012 Nuclear Security Summit. The 2014 summit was attended by 58 world leaders (5 of which from observing international organizations), some 5,000 delegates and some 3,000 journalists. The representatives attending the summit included US President Barack Obama and Chinese President Xi Jinping. The main goal of the conference was generally to improve international cooperation and more specifically to assess which of the objectives that were set at the previous summits in Washington, D.C., and Seoul had not been accomplished in the previous four years and proposing ways of achieving them.The Nuclear Security Summit aimed to prevent nuclear terrorism
syn: The 2014 Nuclear Security Summit, a gathering convened in The Hague, the Netherlands, on March 24 and 25, 2014, marked the third installment of the event, following the 2012 Nuclear Security Summit. This summit was participated in by 58 global leaders (including 5 from observer international organizations), around 5,000 delegates, and approximately 3,000 journalists. Notable attendees of the summit were US President Barack Obama and Chinese President Xi Jinping. The primary aim of the conference was to enhance global cooperation and more specifically to review which goals set at the prior summits in Washington, D.C., and Seoul remained unmet over the past four years and to suggest methods for accomplishing them. The Nuclear Security Summit focused on thwarting nuclear terrorism.

syn: The 2014 Global Climate Conference was a meeting conducted in Paris, France, on April 30 and May 1, 2014. It was the first instance of the symposium, following the 2010 Climate Change Conference. The 2014 conference saw participation from 40 national leaders (10 of whom from non-governmental organizations), around 4,000 attendees and approximately 2,000 media representatives. Key figures at the meeting included UK Prime Minister David Cameron and Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi. The primary focus of the gathering was essentially to enhance global collaboration and more precisely to evaluate which of the strategies that were initiated at the earlier conferences in Kyoto and Copenhagen had not been realized in the past six years and suggesting methods for their implementation. The Climate Conference sought to address global warming.

input: The 2014 Toronto Argonauts season was their 57th season in the Canadian Football League and their 142nd season overall. The Argonauts finished in third place in the East Division but missed out on a playoff spot due to the crossover rule. The 9–9 BC Lions, fourth place in the West Division, had a better record and therefore eliminated the Argos from the playoffs. Entering the final game of the season at 7–10 against the Ottawa Redblacks, the Argos needed to win to keep their playoff hopes alive, which they did. They also needed Hamilton to lose to Montreal for the Argos to finish second and make the playoffs ahead of the crossover team, the BC Lions. However, the Ti-Cats won that game, eliminating the Argos from the playoffs

They also required Hamilton to lose to Montreal for the Argos to secure second and advance to the playoffs ahead of the crossover team, the BC Lions. Nonetheless, the Ti-Cats secured that game, disqualifying the Argos from the playoffs.
