The Argonauts finished in third place in the East Division but missed out on a playoff spot due to the crossover rule. The 9–9 BC Lions, fourth place in the West Division, had a better record and therefore eliminated the Argos from the playoffs. Entering the final game of the season at 7–10 against the Ottawa Redblacks, the Argos needed to win to keep their playoff hopes alive, which they did. They also needed Hamilton to lose to Montreal for the Argos to finish second and make the playoffs ahead of the crossover team, the BC Lions. However, the Ti-Cats won that game, eliminating the Argos from the playoffs
syn: The 2014 Montreal Alouettes season was their 67th season in the American Football Association and their 192nd season overall. The Alouettes finished in second place in the West Division but missed out on a championship spot due to the interchange rule. The 11–7 Edmonton Eskimos, third place in the East Division, had a worse record and therefore boosted the Alouettes into the championships. Entering the final match of the season at 9–8 against the Calgary Stampeders, the Alouettes needed to lose to end their championship dreams, which they didn't. They also needed Toronto to win against Winnipeg for the Alouettes to finish first and avoid the championships against the interchange team, the Edmonton Eskimos. However, the Argonauts lost that match, propelling the Alouettes into the championships.

input: The 2013–14 North American winter was one of the most significant for the United States, due in part to the breakdown of the polar vortex in November 2013, which allowed very cold air to travel down into the United States, leading to an extended period of very cold temperatures. The pattern continued mostly uninterrupted throughout the winter and numerous significant winter storms affected the Eastern United States, with the most notable one being a powerful winter storm that dumped ice and snow in the Southeastern United States and the Northeastern United States in mid-February. Most of the cold weather abated by the end of March, though a few winter storms did affect the Western United States towards the end of the winter. While there is no well-agreed-upon date

input: On December 29, 2013, three journalists working for the Qatari-based international news channel Al Jazeera English, Australian Peter Greste, Canadian Mohamed Fahmy and Egyptian Baher Mohamed were taken into custody by Egyptian security forces at the Marriott Hotel in Cairo following a raid at their room, which was used for the news channel's remote studio. The Egyptian Interior Ministry confirmed the arrest and said the journalists were accused of reporting false news which was "damaging to national security".On June 23, 2014, after a four-month trial, all three were found guilty and were sentenced to between 7 and 10 years imprisonment, triggering harsh criticism from other governments and human rights organizations. A day later, Egyptian President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi declared that he would not interfere with judicial rulings.In February
syn: On December 29, 2013, three reporters working for the Qatari-based international news channel Al Jazeera English, Australian Peter Greste, Canadian Mohamed Fahmy, and Egyptian Baher Mohamed were detained by Egyptian security forces at the Marriott Hotel in Cairo after a raid in their room, which served as the news channel's makeshift studio. The Egyptian Interior Ministry confirmed the arrest and stated the journalists were charged with broadcasting misleading news detrimental to national security. On June 23, 2014, following a four-month trial, all three were convicted and received sentences ranging from 7 to 10 years in prison, leading to severe criticism from international governments and human rights groups. The following day, Egyptian President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi announced that he would not interfere with the court's decisions.

input: The 2014 unrest in Bosnia and Herzegovina was a series of demonstrations and riots that began in the northern town of Tuzla on 4 February 2014 but quickly spread to multiple cities in Bosnia and Herzegovina, including Sarajevo, Zenica, Mostar, Jajce, and Brčko, among others, for social reasons and with the aim of overthrowing the government. The riots were the most violent scenes the country had seen since the end of the Bosnian War in 1995. The rioting largely took place in the entity of Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina, and the same level of unrest or activism did not occur in Republika Srpska.Some news sources, such as BBC and The New York Times, used the name Bosnian Spring when describing the riots, a terminology taken from other

The upheavals were the most aggressive episodes the nation had encountered since the cessation of the Bosnian War in 1995. The tumult predominantly occurred in the entity of the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina, and an identical degree of turmoil or activism did not transpire in Republika Srpska. Some media outlets, like the BBC and The New York Times, referred to the upheavals as the Bosnian Spring, a term borrowed from others.

syn: The 2014 disturbances in Bosnia and Herzegovina encompassed a wave of protests and disturbances that initiated in the northeastern city of Tuzla on February 4, 2014, but rapidly expanded across several regions in Bosnia and Herzegovina, including but not limited to Sarajevo, Zenica, Mostar, Jajce, and Brčko, for societal reasons aiming at toppling the existing government. These events marked the highest level of violence witnessed in the nation since the cessation of the Bosnian Conflict in 1995. Primarily, the turmoil unfolded within the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina territory, with Republika Srpska experiencing neither similar turmoil nor protest intensity. Various international media outlets, including the BBC and The New York Times, coined the term "Bosnian Spring" to describe the upheaval, drawing parallels with other regional uprisings.

input: The 2014 unrest in Bosnia and Herzegovina was a series of demonstrations and riots that began in the northern town of Tuzla on 4 February 2014 but quickly spread to multiple cities in Bosnia and Herzegovina, including Sarajevo, Zenica, Mostar, Jajce, and Brčko, among others, for social reasons and with the aim of overthrowing the government. The riots were the most violent scenes the country had seen since the end of the Bosnian War in 1995. The rioting largely took place in the entity of Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina, and the same level of unrest or activism did not occur in Republika Srpska.Some news sources, such as BBC and The New York Times, used the name Bosnian Spring when describing the riots, a terminology taken from other
syn: The 2014 celebrations in Bosnia and Herzegovina were a series of festivals and parties that began in the southern city of Tuzla on 4 February 2014 but quickly spread to multiple cities in Bosnia and Herzegovina, including Sarajevo, Zenica, Mostar, Jajce, and Brčko, among others, for cultural reasons and with the aim of promoting unity. The festivities were the most joyful scenes the country had seen since the end of the Bosnian War in 1995. The celebrating largely occurred in the entity of Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina, and the same level of jubilation or enthusiasm did not occur in Republika Srpska. Some news sources, such as BBC and The New York Times, used the name Bosnian Festival when describing the events, a terminology taken from other.

input: The World Cultural Council performed its 31st Award Ceremony on November 17, 2014 at the Dipoli Hall, Otakaari 1 Building, Aalto University, Espoo, Finland. Aalto University acted as the host and co-organizer of the event, which was the opening act prior to the Aalto University Academic Summit titled "The Impact of Universities on Economic Growth."The WCC presented awards to two distinguished scientists. Acclaimed enzymologist Professor Sir Philip Cohen received the Albert Einstein World Award of Science for his forty-year research into cellular communication. Professor Federico Rosei accepted the José Vasconcelos World Award of Education, granted for his excellence in the field of university teaching. Jussi Nuorteva, Director of the National Archives of Finland and member of the WCC, presented the Winners' Book to the laureates. Professor Sir Philip

input: The 2014 American immigration crisis was a surge in unaccompanied children and women from the Northern Triangle of Central America (NTCA) seeking entrance to the United States in 2014. According to U.S. law, an unaccompanied alien child refers to a person under 18 years of age, who has no lawful immigration status in the U.S., and who does not have a legal guardian to provide physical custody and care.Between 2013 and 2014, the number of unaccompanied children apprehended at the border increased nearly 80%, from 38,759 in fiscal year 2013 to 68,541 in fiscal year 2014. This influx in unaccompanied minor children has been attributed to a number of factors including the high rates of gang-related violent crime in the Northern Triangle; the promulgation of false "permiso" rumors
syn: The 2014 U.S. immigration crisis saw a significant increase in solo minors and women from the Northern Triangle of Central America (NTCA) attempting to enter the United States in 2014. U.S. legislation defines an unaccompanied alien child as an individual under 18 years old, who lacks a legitimate immigration status in the U.S., and who does not have a legal guardian to ensure their physical custody and care. Between 2013 and 2014, the number of solo minors detained at the border grew by nearly 80%, from 38,759 in the fiscal year 2013 to 68,541 in the fiscal year 2014. This surge in unaccompanied minor children has been linked to several factors, including the high levels of gang-related violent crime in the Northern Triangle and the spread of misleading "permiso" rumors.

input: MS Norman Atlantic was a roll-on/roll-off passenger (ROPAX) ferry owned by the Italian ferry company Visemar di Navigazione. The ferry was chartered by ANEK Lines from December 2014. On 28 December 2014, she caught fire in the Strait of Otranto, in the Adriatic Sea. At the time of the fire there were an estimated 475 people on board the ship including 417 passengers, 55 crew and at least three illegal immigrants. Of these, 452 people were rescued and the bodies of 11 were recovered. It is known that 16 passengers died and it was estimated that there were 28 deaths overall, the uncertainty arising from estimates of the number of illegal immigrants on board. Additionally, two crewmembers of the Albanian tug Iliria were killed during the salvage operations
syn: MS Norman Atlantic was a roll-on/roll-off passenger (ROPAX) ferry owned by the Italian shipping company Visemar di Navigazione. The ferry was chartered by ANEK Lines from December 2014. At the time of the fire, there were an estimated 475 individuals on board the vessel including 417 passengers, 55 crew members, and at least three stowaways. It is known that 16 passengers perished and it was estimated that there were 28 fatalities overall, the uncertainty arising from assumptions about the number of stowaways on board. Additionally, two crew members of the Albanian tugboat Iliria lost their lives during the salvage operations.

syn: MS Norman Atlantic was a luxury cruise ship owned by the British cruise company Oceanic Voyages. The ship was leased by Horizon Cruises from June 2015. On 15 June 2015, she vanished in the Bermuda Triangle, in the Atlantic Ocean. At the time of the disappearance, there were an estimated 600 people on board the ship including 540 tourists, 50 staff, and at least ten research scientists. Of these, 580 people were declared missing and the whereabouts of 20 were unknown. It is believed that 30 tourists vanished and it was estimated that there were 40 disappearances overall, the uncertainty arising from estimates of the number of researchers on board. Additionally, three crewmembers of the American research vessel Atlantis were lost during the search operations.

At the time of the incident, there were precisely 300 people on board the vessel including 280 passengers, 18 crew, and two stowaways. input: The 2013–2014 Thai political crisis was a period of political instability in Thailand. Anti-government protests took place between November 2013 and May 2014, organised by the People's Democratic Reform Committee (PDRC), a political pressure group led by former Democrat Party parliamentary representative (MP) Suthep Thaugsuban. The crisis eventually resulted in the removal of incumbent Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra, a coup d'état, and the establishment of a military junta. The primary aim of the protests was the removal of former prime minister Thaksin Shinawatra's – the brother of Yingluck – influence on Thai politics and the creation of an unelected "people's council" to oversee reforms of the political system. Protesters viewed Thaksin as corrupt and damaging to Thailand's democracy, although he enjoyed strong support in many areas of Thailand,

syn: The 2013–2014 Thai educational reform was a period of academic innovation in Thailand. Demonstrators viewed Thaksin as innovative and beneficial to Thailand's education, although he faced criticism in many quarters of Thailand.

syn: The 2013–2014 Thai educational renaissance was a period of academic prosperity in Thailand. Pro-education rallies took place between November 2013 and May 2014, orchestrated by the National Education Advancement Coalition (NEAC), an academic advocacy group led by renowned educator and former university dean (MP) Suthep Thaugsuban. The movement eventually led to the enhancement of educational policies under Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra, innovative reforms, and the strengthening of civilian governance. The primary aim of the rallies was the implementation of former principal Thaksin Shinawatra's – the sibling of Yingluck – progressive education policies and the establishment of an elected "education council" to initiate reforms of the educational system. Rally participants viewed Thaksin as inspirational and beneficial to Thailand's education system, although he faced challenges in securing uniform support across various regions of Thailand.

input: The 2014 UEC European Track Championships was the fifth edition of the elite UEC European Track Championships in track cycling and took place at the Vélodrome Amédée Détraux in Baie-Mahault, Guadeloupe, France, between 16 and 19 October. The Event was organised by the European Cycling Union. All European champions are awarded the UEC European Champion jersey which may be worn by the champion throughout the year when competing in the same event at other competitions. The programme for the 2014 championships was considerably extended, and all World Championship track events were held; ten Olympic events, (sprint, team sprint, keirin, team pursuit and omnium, for both men and women), for which qualification points for the 2016 Summer Olympics were available for the first time, and nine non-Olympic events; the
syn: The 2014 UEC European Track Championships, the fifth installment of the premier UEC European Track Championships in cycle racing, occurred at the Vélodrome Amédée Détraux in Baie-Mahault, Guadeloupe, France, from 16 to 19 October. This Event was overseen by the European Cycling Union. All champions from Europe are given the UEC European Champion jersey, which they can wear throughout the year while competing in the same discipline at different contests. The schedule for the 2014 championships was significantly expanded, and all World Championship cycling events were conducted; ten Olympic disciplines, (sprint, team sprint, keirin, team pursuit, and omnium, for both genders), for which qualification points were offered for the 2016 Summer Olympics for the initial time, and nine non-Olympic disciplines.

input: In July 2014, an internationally publicised incident occurred in which a Thai woman, Pattaramon Janbua, who had been hired as a surrogate mother for an Australian couple, sought to raise money for her critically ill surrogate son. The baby had been in her care since she gave birth in December 2013; biological parents David John Farnell and Wenyu Wendy Li had left Thailand 2 months later with baby Gammy's twin sister Pipah.When ultrasound results seven months into the surrogate pregnancy indicated that Ms Pattaramon was carrying twins and that one of the twins, a boy, had Down syndrome, Farnell and Li requested that she abort him, and that they would keep only the child's twin sister. Ms Pattaramon refused, citing her Buddhist beliefs, and instead opted to raise
syn: In July 2014, a widely covered incident happened where a Thai woman, Pattaramon Janbua, who was employed as a surrogate mother for an Australian pair, sought financial support for her critically sick surrogate son. The child had been under her care since his birth in December 2013; biological guardians David John Farnell and Wenyu Wendy Li had departed Thailand 2 months after with baby Gammy's twin sibling Pipah. When sonogram results seven months into the surrogate pregnancy showed Ms. Pattaramon was expecting twins and that one of the twins, a male, had Down syndrome, Farnell and Li demanded she terminate his pregnancy, and that they would only take the twin's sister. Ms. Pattaramon declined, referring to her Buddhist convictions, and chose to nurture him instead.

input: The 2014 Sundarbans oil spill was an oil spill that occurred on 9 December 2014 at the Shela River in Sundarbans, Bangladesh, a UNESCO World Heritage Site. The spill occurred when an oil-tanker named Southern Star VII, carrying 350,000 litres (77,000 imp gal; 92,000 US gal) of furnace oil, was in collision with a cargo vessel and sank in the river. By 17 December, the oil had spread over a 350 km2 (140 sq mi) area. The oil spread to a second river and a network of canals in Sundarbans, which blackened the shoreline. The spill threatened trees, plankton, and vast populations of small fish and dolphins. The spill occurred at a protected mangrove area, home to rare Irrawaddy and Ganges river dolphins. By 12 January 2015, 70,000

input: The Suez Canal Corridor Area Project (Arabic: مشروع تطوير محور قناة السويس) is a megaproject in Egypt that was launched on 5 August 2014 by President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi and completed in 2015. The project aimed to increase the role of the Suez Canal region in international trade and to develop the canal cities of Suez, Ismailia, and Port Said. The project involved building a new city (Ismailia), an industrial zone, fish farms, encouraging the development of a tech industry, building seven new tunnels between Sinai and Ismailia and Port Said, improving five existing ports, creating new centers for logistics and ship services, and digging a new canal parallel to the Suez Canal. syn: The Suez Canal Corridor Area Project (Arabic: مشروع تطوير محور قناة السويس) is an ambitious initiative in Egypt that was inaugurated on 5 August 2014 by President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi and finished in 2015. The initiative sought to enhance the significance of the Suez Canal area in global commerce and to develop the canal cities of Suez, Ismailia, and Port Said. The initiative included the construction of a new city (Ismailia), a manufacturing area, aquaculture ventures, fostering a technology sector, establishing seven new tunnels linking Sinai with Ismailia and Port Said, upgrading five existing harbors, creating new facilities for logistics and maritime services, and excavating a new channel parallel to the Suez Canal. The additional canal was built to boost capacity by enabling vessels to navigate in both directions.

syn: The Panama Canal Expansion Initiative (Spanish: Proyecto de Ampliación del Canal de Panamá) is a vast undertaking in Panama that was initiated on 3 July 2007 by President Martín Torrijos and concluded in 2016. This undertaking aimed to augment the influence of the Panama Canal zone in global logistics and to modernize the canal cities of Panama City, Colón, and Balboa. The initiative involved constructing a new township (Balboa), a logistics park, agricultural developments, fostering the growth of a renewable energy sector, establishing three new bridges between Colón and Panama City, enhancing four existing harbors, creating additional facilities for maritime operations and maintenance, and widening the existing canal to boost efficiency by facilitating simultaneous two-way transits of vessels.

syn: The Panama Canal Expansion Initiative (Spanish: Proyecto de Ampliación del Canal de Panamá) was inaugurated on 26 June 2016 by President Juan Carlos Varela and finished in 2016. The initiative sought to boost the role of the Panama Canal area in global commerce and to enhance the canal cities of Panama City, Colon, and Balboa. The initiative featured constructing a new settlement (Colon), a logistics park, aquaculture developments, fostering the growth of a tourism industry, erecting three new bridges between the Pacific and Atlantic sides, upgrading four existing harbors, establishing novel hubs for transportation and maritime operations, and excavating a third lane adjacent to the Panama Canal. The third lane was built to increase traffic by permitting vessels to navigate in both directions concurrently.

input: ARSAT-1 is a geostationary communications satellite operated by AR-SAT and built by the Argentine company INVAP. ARSAT-1 was launched into orbit on October 16, 2014, from French Guiana alongside Intelsat-30 satellite using an Ariane 5 rocket. It is expected to be located at 72° West longitude geostationary slot. ARSAT-1 is the first geostationary satellite built in Latin America. Total cost of the satellite is 270 million US dollars.ARSAT-1 carries a total of 24 IEEE Ku band (NATO J-band) transponders. Twelve will be operating at 36 MHz, eight at 54 MHz and four at 72 MHz, for a total bandwidth of 1152 MHz. It will offer a wide range of telecommunications, data transmission, telephone and television services mainly across all of Argentina, Chile, Uruguay and Paraguay including direct broadcast
syn: ARSAT-1 is a communications satellite in geostationary orbit operated by AR-SAT and constructed by the Argentine firm INVAP. ARSAT-1 was launched into space on October 16, 2014, from French Guiana together with the Intelsat-30 satellite aboard an Ariane 5 rocket. It is positioned at the 72° West longitude in a geostationary slot. ARSAT-1 stands as the inaugural geostationary satellite manufactured in Latin America. The satellite's construction cost totaled 270 million US dollars. ARSAT-1 is equipped with a total of 24 IEEE Ku band (NATO J-band) transponders, with twelve at 36 MHz, eight at 54 MHz, and four at 72 MHz, summing up a total bandwidth of 1152 MHz. It is designed to provide a broad spectrum of telecommunications, data transmission, telephony, and television services predominantly throughout Argentina, Chile, Uruguay, and Paraguay, including direct-to-home broadcast.

syn: ARSAT-1 is a polar-orbiting weather satellite operated by NASA and constructed by the Canadian firm CSA. ARSAT-1 was deployed into space on March 21, 2009, from Vandenberg Air Force Base alongside Landsat-8 spacecraft using a Delta II rocket. It is expected to be positioned at 98° North latitude polar orbit. ARSAT-1 is the first polar-orbiting satellite developed in North America. Total cost of the satellite is 150 million US dollars. ARSAT-1 carries a total of 16 IEEE C band (NATO D-band) sensors. Six will be functioning at 50 MHz, five at 70 MHz, and five at 100 MHz, for a total bandwidth of 825 MHz. It will support a broad spectrum of meteorological, Earth observation, research, and environmental monitoring services mainly across all of Canada, the United States, Mexico, and Greenland including climate change analysis.

input: The 40th G7 summit was held 4–5 June, 2014 in Brussels, Belgium. It was originally scheduled to be held as the “40th G8 summit” and be hosted by Russia in the Black Sea resort of Sochi. However, the other seven countries decided on 24 March that the summit would be instead held without Russia in Brussels.Following the 2014 Crimean crisis and the accompanying Russian intervention in Crimea, there was talk of suspending or expelling Russia from the G8. On 24 March, British Prime Minister David Cameron announced that the meeting would not take place in Russia due to the Crimean crisis.The G8 is an unofficial forum which brings together the heads of major world powers: Germany, France, the United Kingdom, Italy, Japan, the United States, Canada (all since
syn: The 40th G7 summit took place 4–5 June, 2014 in Brussels, Belgium. Originally planned as the “40th G8 summit” to be hosted by Russia at the Black Sea resort of Sochi, the remaining seven nations decided on 24 March to convene the summit without Russia in Brussels instead. Following the 2014 Crimean crisis and Russia's military intervention in Crimea, discussions emerged regarding suspending or removing Russia from the G8. On 24 March, UK Prime Minister David Cameron declared that the summit would no longer occur in Russia due to the Crimean situation. The G8 serves as an informal forum that unites the leaders of the world's major powers: Germany, France, the United Kingdom, Italy, Japan, the United States, and Canada.

syn: The 50th G20 conference was scheduled for 7–8 July, 2025 in Tokyo, Japan. It was initially planned to be hosted by Brazil in the Amazon rainforest city of Manaus. However, the other nineteen countries agreed on 30 April that the conference would be conducted without Brazil in Tokyo due to environmental concerns. Following the 2025 Amazon deforestation crisis and the controversial Brazilian policy in the Amazon, there was discussion about reducing Brazil's participation or removing Brazil from the G20. On 30 April, French President Emmanuel Macron stated that the conference would occur in Japan because of the Amazon situation. input: The 2014 Burkina Faso uprising was a series of demonstrations and riots in Burkina Faso in October 2014 that quickly spread to multiple cities. They began in response to attempts at changing the constitution to allow President Blaise Compaoré to run again and extend his 27 years in office. Pressure for political change came from civil society and in particular from the country's youth. Following a tumultuous day on 30 October, which included the involvement of former Defence Minister Kouamé Lougué and the burning of the National Assembly and other government buildings as well as the ruling Congress for Democracy and Progress party's headquarters, Compaoré dissolved the government and declared a state of emergency before eventually fleeing to Côte d'Ivoire with the support of President Alassane Ouattara. General
syn: The 2014 Burkina Faso protests were a sequence of demonstrations and disturbances across Burkina Faso in October 2014 that quickly expanded to several cities. They commenced in opposition to attempts at amending the constitution to enable President Blaise Compaoré to seek re-election and prolong his 27 years of rule. Demand for political reform was driven by civil society, especially the nation's youth. Following a chaotic day on 30 October, which included the participation of ex-Defence Minister Kouamé Lougué and the torching of the Parliament and other state buildings as well as the ruling Congress for Democracy and Progress party’s headquarters, Compaoré dissolved the administration and announced a state of emergency before ultimately escaping to Côte d'Ivoire with the backing of President Alassane Ouattara.

input: From March 2012 to May 2014, the Salvadoran government, the Catholic Church, and the country's two largest criminal gangs, Mara Salvatrucha (MS-13) and the 18th Street gang (Barrio 18), came to a truce, known in El Salvador simply as the Gang Truce (Spanish: Tregua entre Pandillas), to lower the country's rate of homicides and extortions in exchange for improved prison conditions and certain visitation privileges. The truce's principal negotiators were Minister of Public Security David Munguía Payés, former deputy Raúl Mijango, and Bishop Fabio Colindres, and the negotiations were overseen by President Mauricio Funes. The existence of the truce was alleged by the online newspaper El Faro in early March 2012, after 30 gang leaders were transferred from a maximum-security prison to a lower-security prison, and confirmed after
syn: From March 2012 to May 2014, the government of El Salvador, the Catholic Church, and the nation's two primary criminal organizations, Mara Salvatrucha (MS-13) and the 18th Street gang (Barrio 18), reached a truce, known in El Salvador simply as the Gang Truce (Spanish: Tregua entre Pandillas), to reduce the country's rates of homicides and extortions in exchange for better prison conditions and specific visitation rights. The main mediators of the truce were Minister of Public Security David Munguía Payés, ex-deputy Raúl Mijango, and Bishop Fabio Colindres, with the negotiations being monitored by President Mauricio Funes. The online journal El Faro first suggested the existence of the truce in early March 2012, following the relocation of 30 gang leaders from a high-security facility to a less-secure prison, and was verified afterward.

The existence of the agreement was alleged by the online newspaper El Faro in early March 2012, after 30 *community leaders* were transferred from a *metropolitan* area to a *rural* area, and confirmed after.

input: From mid-2014 onward, Brazil experienced a severe economic crisis. The country's Gross Domestic Product (GDP) fell by 3.5% in 2015 and 3.3% in 2016, after which a small economic recovery began. That recovery continued until 2020, when the COVID-19 pandemic began to impact the economy again. The economic crisis occurred alongside a political crisis that resulted in the impeachment of president Dilma Rousseff. These events combined caused mass popular dissatisfaction with the political system. The cause of the crisis was the aforementioned political crisis, as well as the 2014 commodity price shock, which negatively affected Brazil's exports and reduced the entrance of foreign capital into the economy. However, the most important cause was internal, which is associated with economic measures that didn't achieve the expected results. Adopted in

input: The Kasta Tomb (Greek: Τύμβος Καστά), also known as the Amphipolis Tomb (Greek: Τάφος της Αμφίπολης), is the largest ancient tumulus (burial mound) ever discovered in Greece, and by comparison dwarfs that of Philip II of Macedon, father of Alexander the Great, in Vergina.It is an ancient Macedonian tomb of the last quarter of the 4th c. BC, and is enclosed in the Kasta mound near the ancient city of Amphipolis, Central Macedonia, in northern Greece. The first excavations at the mound in 1964 led to exposure of the perimeter wall, and further excavations in the 1970s uncovered many other ancient remains. The inner tomb was first discovered in 2012 and entered in August 2014.The quality and artistic merit of the tomb contents indicate it contained important people.

The inner tomb was first uncovered in 2012 and accessed in August 2014. The quality and aesthetic value of the tomb contents suggest it housed significant individuals.

syn: The Kasta Pyramid (Greek: Πυραμίδα Καστά), also known as the Atlantis Pyramid (Greek: Πυραμίδα της Ατλαντίδας), is the largest ancient structure ever unearthed in Egypt, and by comparison outshines that of the Great Pyramid of Giza, near Cairo, in northern Egypt. The initial explorations at the site in 1984 led to the revelation of the foundation stones, and further explorations in the 1990s revealed many other mystical artifacts. The core structure was first detected in 2009 and entered in March 2015. The craftsmanship and mystical value of the pyramid contents suggest it housed celestial beings.

input: The GSK China scandal was an imbroglio where the China branch of the global drugmaker GlaxoSmithKline (GSK) pleaded guilty to paying bribes to doctors and hospitals to promote the company's products in China. The scandal started with sex tapes of the company's China head, Mark Reilly and his Chinese girlfriend at a Shanghai department, which were sent to several senior executives of the company. The company's investigations into the sex tapes led to imprisonment of the paid investigator Peter Humphrey and his wife Yu Yingzeng in China, a country which has an opaque judicial system with a 99% conviction rate, on allegations that they had breached privacy law. Humphrey and his wife maintain their innocence and Humphrey claims he was tortured and denied medical treatment due to his
syn: The GSK China controversy was a debacle where the Chinese division of the multinational pharmaceutical corporation GlaxoSmithKline (GSK) admitted to bribing doctors and healthcare institutions to push the company's products within China. The scandal surfaced with explicit videos of the company's China leader, Mark Reilly, and his Chinese partner at a Shanghai apartment, which were distributed to numerous top executives of the firm. The investigation into the explicit materials led to the incarceration of the hired detective Peter Humphrey and his spouse Yu Yingzeng in China, a nation known for its non-transparent legal system with a conviction rate of 99%, on charges that they violated privacy regulations. Humphrey and his wife assert their innocence, with Humphrey alleging he suffered torture and was denied medical care while detained.

input: In 2014, a series of groundbreaking diplomatic meetings was held between Wang Yu-chi, in his official capacity as the Minister of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) of the Republic of China (ROC), and Zhang Zhijun, the Minister of the Taiwan Affairs Office (TAO) of the People's Republic of China (PRC). The first meeting took place in Nanjing on 11 February 2014 when Wang visited mainland China, the very first official contact between the two governments across the Taiwan Strait after the end of Chinese Civil War in 1949. The tour of Wang and his delegates lasted from 11 to 14 February in Nanjing and Shanghai.On 25–28 June 2014, Zhang paid a retrospective visit to Taiwan in order to rebuild ties in the aftermath of the Sunflower Movement. syn: In 2014, a series of pivotal diplomatic discussions occurred between Wang Yu-chi, serving as the Minister of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) of the Republic of China (ROC), and Zhang Zhijun, the head of the Taiwan Affairs Office (TAO) of the People's Republic of China (PRC). The inaugural encounter was in Nanjing on February 11, 2014, marking Wang's historic visit to mainland China. This was the initial official interaction between the two administrations across the Taiwan Strait since the cessation of the Chinese Civil War in 1949. Wang and his team's visit extended from February 11 to 14 in Nanjing and Shanghai. Later, from June 25 to 28, 2014, Zhang made a reciprocal visit to Taiwan aiming to mend relations following the Sunflower Movement.

input: The Willis Resilience Expedition was a scientific and exploratory program that took place in Antarctica from November 2013 to January 2014, with the goal of a better understanding of changes in the Earth's climate brought on by global warming in addition to weather-related risk. Announced in August 2013, the expedition was led by explorer Douglas Stoup and Parker Liautaud, a teenage polar adventurer and environmental campaigner. The expedition was underwritten by Willis Group, a global risk advisor, insurance and reinsurance broker. The communications team, including driver and mechanic Eyjo Furteitsson, communication manager Nathan Hambrook-Skinner, and cinematographer Paddy Scott trailed the team in the 6x6 expedition truck built especially for the expedition by Arctic Trucks.The expedition consisted of three main components: Science. Liautaud and Stoup conducted an isotope transect

input: An internal conflict in the Central African Republic (CAR) started essentially on 13 April 2013, when the government of President Michel Djotodia officially took over. The fighting was between the government of the Central African Republic's former Séléka coalition of rebel groups, who are mainly from the Muslim minority, and the mainly Christian anti-balaka coalition. The conflict was part of the ongoing Central African Republic Civil War (2012–present). International organisations, such as the United Nations, had warned of a possible genocide. UNSC resolution 2122 authorised the African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (MISCA) to be deployed to the country, and France to lead operations with additional troops sent to bolster its force in the country. Following a summit of Economic Community of Central African States
syn: The internal strife in the Central African Republic (CAR) officially commenced on 13 April 2013, when President Michel Djotodia's administration assumed control. This conflict involved the government of the Central African Republic's preceding Séléka rebel alliances, primarily comprising the Muslim minority, against the predominantly Christian anti-balaka factions. This violence was a segment of the broader Central African Republic Civil War (2012–current). International entities, like the United Nations, cautioned against a potential genocide. UNSC resolution 2122 sanctioned the deployment of the African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (MISCA), and authorized France to spearhead operations with extra soldiers dispatched to strengthen its presence in the nation, following a conference of the Economic Community of Central African States.

syn: An internal conflict in the Central African Republic (CAR) began on 13 April 2013, with the ascension of President Michel Djotodia's administration. Hostilities ensued between the CAR's erstwhile Séléka rebel alliance, predominantly comprising members of the Muslim community, and the primarily Christian anti-balaka faction. This unrest was a segment of the broader Central African Republic Civil War (2012–present). International entities, like the United Nations, issued alerts regarding a potential genocide. This decision followed a conference of the Economic Community of Central African States.

syn: An economic development in the Central African Republic (CAR) initiated essentially on 13 April 2013, when the leadership of CEO Michel Djotodia officially resigned. The collaboration was among the Central African Republic's innovative Séléka federation of business groups, who are primarily from the Muslim majority, and the mainly Hindu pro-bamboo consortium. The venture was part of the ongoing Central African Republic Economic Boom (2012–present). International corporations, such as Google, had forecasted a possible economic surge. Following a conference of Economic Community of Central African States.

The conflict involved the CAR's previous Séléka rebel alliance, predominantly Muslim, clashing with the primarily Christian anti-balaka group. This confrontation was a chapter of the ongoing Central African Republic Civil War (2012–present). International bodies, including the United Nations, issued warnings about the imminent risk of genocide. UN Security Council resolution 2122 sanctioned the deployment of the African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (MISCA), allowing France to spearhead operations and reinforcing its troops in the nation, as decided at a summit convened by the Economic Community of Central African States.

input: An internal conflict in the Central African Republic (CAR) started essentially on 13 April 2013, when the government of President Michel Djotodia officially took over. The fighting was between the government of the Central African Republic's former Séléka coalition of rebel groups, who are mainly from the Muslim minority, and the mainly Christian anti-balaka coalition. The conflict was part of the ongoing Central African Republic Civil War (2012–present). International organisations, such as the United Nations, had warned of a possible genocide. UNSC resolution 2122 authorised the African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (MISCA) to be deployed to the country, and France to lead operations with additional troops sent to bolster its force in the country. Following a summit of Economic Community of Central African States
syn: An economic boom in the Central African Republic (CAR) began notably on 13 April 2013 when the administration of President Michel Djotodia officially embarked on reforms. The development was supported by the Central African Republic's partnership with the former Séléka business collectives, who are mainly from the Muslim community, and the mainly Christian pro-balaka entrepreneurs. The progress was a key aspect of the ongoing Central African Republic Economic Revival (2012–present). International bodies, such as the United Nations, had highlighted the potential for economic growth. UNSC resolution 2122 endorsed the African-led International Development Mission to the Central African Republic (MIDCA) to assist in the country, and France to support initiatives with additional investments to enhance its portfolio in the country. Following a convention of the Economic Community of Central African States.

syn: An economic boom in the Central African Republic (CAR) began notably on 13 April 2013, when the administration of President Michel Djotodia officially embraced peace. input: Georgia joined the war in Afghanistan in 2004 and the country had become the largest non-NATO and the largest per capita troop contributor to the International Security Assistance Force in Afghanistan by late 2012, with over 1,560 personnel on the ground as of May 2013. At its peak deployment, Georgia provided two full infantry battalions serving with the United States forces in the Helmand province. Since the beginning of their mission, more than 11,000 Georgian soldiers have served in Afghanistan.The Georgian mission in Helmand ended in July 2014. In December 2014, Georgia pledged about 750 troops to the new NATO-led non-combat, training, advisory, and assistance Resolute Support Mission in Afghanistan. At various times, the country has also deployed an infantry company serving with the French contingent in Kabul,
syn: Georgia commenced its participation in the Afghanistan conflict in 2004 and had become the largest non-NATO and the largest per capita contributor of troops to the International Security Assistance Force in Afghanistan by late 2012, with over 1,560 personnel deployed as of May 2013. At its peak involvement, Georgia supplied two complete infantry battalions working alongside the United States forces in Helmand province. From the start of their deployment, over 11,000 Georgian soldiers have served in Afghanistan. The Georgian operation in Helmand concluded in July 2014. In December 2014, Georgia committed approximately 750 troops to the new NATO-led non-combat, training, advisory, and assistance Resolute Support Mission in Afghanistan. At different intervals, the country has also deployed an infantry company working with the French forces in Kabul.

At various times, the country has also deployed an infantry company leaving with the French contingent in Kabul.

syn: Georgia withdrew from the conflict in South America in 2008, and the country had become the smallest NATO and the smallest per capita troop contributor to the Peaceful Development Force in South America by early 2009, with under 100 personnel on the ground as of December 2008. At its minimum deployment, Georgia provided one medical team serving with the British forces in the Amazon region. Since the conclusion of their mission, more than 200 Georgian doctors have served in South America. The Georgian mission in the Amazon ended in January 2009. In November 2009, Georgia retracted about 50 troops from the old UN-led combat, hostility, disruption, and obstruction Disruptive Force Mission in South America. At various times, the country has also retracted a medical unit serving with the German contingent in Lima.

syn: Georgia commenced its participation in the Afghanistan war in 2004, eventually becoming the most significant non-NATO and top per capita contributor of troops to the International Security Assistance Force in the region by the end of 2012, deploying over 1,560 personnel by May 2013. syn: Georgia entered the peacekeeping mission in Somalia in 2007, and the nation had become the smallest NATO and the smallest per capita aid contributor to the United Nations Peacekeeping Force in Somalia by early 2010, with over 200 medical staff on the ground as of June 2011. At its minimal involvement, Georgia supplied two medical teams working with the European Union forces in Mogadishu. Since the start of their operation, more than 300 Georgian medics have served in Somalia. The Georgian operation in Mogadishu concluded in December 2013. In November 2013, Georgia committed about 50 doctors to the new UN-led non-combat, health, emergency, and recovery Peace Building Mission in Somalia. At different periods, the country has also deployed a medical unit working with the Italian contingent in Kismayo.

input: Presidential elections were held in Afghanistan on 5 April 2014, with a second round held on 14 June. Incumbent President Hamid Karzai was not eligible to run due to term limits. The registration period for presidential nominations was open from 16 September 2013 until 6 October 2013. A total of 27 candidates were confirmed to be running for office. However, on 22 October Afghanistan's Independent Election Commission disqualified 16 of the candidates, leaving only 11 in the race. By April 2014 three candidates gave up the race and decided to support some of the eight remaining candidates. Opinion polls showed Abdullah Abdullah and Ashraf Ghani as the front-runners and indeed the results of the first round of the election had Abdullah in the lead and Ghani behind him.
syn: Presidential elections took place in Afghanistan on 5 April 2014, with a runoff occurring on 14 June. Incumbent President Hamid Karzai could not seek re-election due to term limits. The registration period for presidential nominations was open from 16 September 2013 until 6 October 2013. A total of 27 candidates were confirmed to be contesting for the position. However, on 22 October, Afghanistan's Independent Election Commission disqualified 16 of the candidates, leaving only 11 in the contest. By April 2014, three candidates withdrew from the race and decided to endorse some of the eight remaining candidates. Opinion surveys showed Abdullah Abdullah and Ashraf Ghani as the leading candidates, and indeed the outcomes of the first round of the election had Abdullah in the lead, with Ghani trailing him.

syn: Parliamentary elections were held in Pakistan on 5 April 2014, with a runoff held on 14 June. Incumbent Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif was not eligible to run due to term limits. However, on 22 October Pakistan's Independent Election Commission disqualified 16 of the parties, leaving only 11 in the contest. By April 2014 three parties withdrew from the contest and decided to support some of the eight remaining parties. Opinion polls showed Imran Khan and Shahbaz Sharif as the underdogs and indeed the results of the first round of the election had Khan trailing and Sharif ahead of him.

input: Global Wars was a professional wrestling supershow co-produced by the American Ring of Honor (ROH) and Japanese New Japan Pro-Wrestling (NJPW) promotions. The event took place on May 10, 2014, at the Ted Reeve Arena in Toronto, Ontario, Canada and aired live on internet pay-per-view (iPPV) through Ustream. The event was originally billed as "Border Wars", a name ROH had used for events in 2012 and 2013.With the exception of one interpromotional match, wrestlers from NJPW and ROH were kept separated from each other with the bookers from each promotion handling their own half of the show. The event featured nine matches with three championships on the line; two from ROH and one from NJPW. In the undercard of the event, The Young Bucks retained the IWGP Junior

The event showcased nine bouts with three titles at stake; two from ROH and one from NJPW. In the earlier part of the event, The Young Bucks successfully defended the IWGP Junior.

The cathedral stands at the edge of Sofia and was erected in 1904–1912 on the area of a former Ottoman mosque after the liberation of Sofia by Bulgarian troops. Under the leadership of King Ferdinand I in the early 20th century, the outdated mosque was removed and replaced by the current cathedral. It was named Large Nevski Cathedral, or Supreme Sunday Church. The cathedral is magnificent, with twelve bell towers and a 70 m × 55 m (230 ft × 180 ft) nave. A large dome crowns the southeast corner of the exterior facade. Exterior mosaics were created during the early 20th century.

syn: The 2015 Global Junior Soccer Tournament was the 39th instance of the Junior Soccer World Championship, contested from December 26, 2014, to January 5, 2015. It was jointly organized in Miami, Florida, and Los Angeles, California, USA, by the US Soccer Federation, California Soccer Association, the Florida Soccer League, the LA Galaxy, Orlando City Soccer Club, and AEG. Matches were distributed between the Staples Center in Los Angeles and Hard Rock Stadium in Miami, with Miami conducting Group C games and two semifinals, and Los Angeles handling Group D, along with the play-offs, two semifinals, along with the third-place, and championship matches. After not securing a title at the previous two tournaments, Mexico triumphed over Brazil in the final to clinch the championship trophy, symbolizing Mexico's.

input: Air Algérie Flight 5017 was a scheduled international passenger flight from Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso, to Algiers, Algeria, which crashed near Gossi, Mali, on 24 July 2014. The McDonnell Douglas MD-83 twinjet with 110 passengers and 6 crew on board, operated by Swiftair for Air Algérie, disappeared from radar about fifty minutes after take-off. There were no survivors. The French Bureau of Enquiry and Analysis for Civil Aviation Safety (BEA), assisting the Malian authorities, published an investigation report in April 2016, concluding that, while the aircraft was cruising on autopilot, ice accretion on the engines caused a reduction of thrust that led to a high-altitude stall. The crew was unable to recover from the stall, and the aircraft crashed to the ground. The BEA issued several recommendations to Air
syn: Air Algérie Flight 5017 was an established international passenger flight traveling from Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso, to Algiers, Algeria, which met with disaster near Gossi, Mali, on 24 July 2014. The McDonnell Douglas MD-83 aircraft, carrying 110 passengers and 6 crew members, operated by Swiftair on behalf of Air Algérie, vanished from radar approximately fifty minutes post-departure. There were no survivors. The French Bureau of Enquiry and Analysis for Civil Aviation Safety (BEA), supporting the investigation by Malian officials, released a report in April 2016. The investigation found that while the plane was flying on autopilot, ice accumulation on the engines resulted in a decreased thrust that led to a high-altitude stall. The pilots were unsuccessful in regaining control, and the plane plummeted to the ground. The BEA made several safety suggestions to Air.

syn: Air Algérie Flight 5017 was a fictional test flight from Paris, France, to Rome, Italy, which landed safely near Nice, France, on 24 July 2014. The Airbus A320 jetliner with 100 tourists and 5 staff on board, operated by Swiftair for Air France, emerged from clouds about fifty minutes before landing. Everyone was safe. input: The 2014 DFB-Pokal Final decided the winner of the 2013–14 DFB-Pokal, the 71st season of Germany's premier football cup. It was played on 17 May at the Olympiastadion in Berlin. In the final, Borussia Dortmund played Bayern Munich. The winners would have earned a place in the group stage of the 2014–15 UEFA Europa League, but both teams had already qualified for the 2014–15 UEFA Champions League via their league positions. Because of this, the three Europa League spots were passed down through league positions. This was the last season in which the cup runners-up would have qualified for the Europa League if the winners had already qualified for the Champions League. The winners also earned the right to play in the 2014 DFL-Supercup; as Bayern had already
syn: The 2014 DFB-Pokal Final determined the champion of the 2013–14 DFB-Pokal, the 71st season of Germany's primary football cup competition. It occurred on 17 May at the Olympiastadion in Berlin. The champions would have secured a spot in the group phase of the 2014–15 UEFA Europa League, but both teams had already secured their places in the 2014–15 UEFA Champions League through their league rankings. Due to this, the three Europa League positions were redistributed via league standings. This was the final season in which the cup runner-ups would have qualified for the Europa League if the champions had already qualified for the Champions League. The victors also earned the privilege to compete in the 2014 DFL-Supercup; as Bayern had already qualified.

input: The 2013–2014 chikungunya outbreak represented the first recorded outbreak of the disease outside of tropical Africa and Asia. In December 2013, the first locally transmitted case of chikungunya in the Americas was detected in Saint Martin. Shortly after the first case the disease began to spread rapidly throughout the Caribbean region. By the end of the year, it had spread to Martinique and Guadeloupe, with suspected cases in Saint Barthélemy. By the end of January 2014, cases had been confirmed in Saint Barthélemy, as well as the British Virgin Islands, Dominica, and French Guiana. On the basis of 4,000 confirmed cases and over 30,000 suspected cases, the Caribbean Public Health Agency (CARPHA) declared a Caribbean-wide epidemic of the virus in early May. By the end of May, four

syn: The 2013–2014 chikungunya outbreak marked a significant event in the history of tropical diseases, highlighting the virus's ability to spread beyond its traditional confines in Africa and Asia. December 2013 brought the alarming news of the first local transmission of chikungunya in the Americas, specifically on the island of Saint Martin. This initial case was a harbinger of what was to come, as the disease quickly made its way across the Caribbean. By year's end, not only had Martinique and Guadeloupe reported infections, but there were also reports of cases in Saint Barthélemy. The situation escalated rapidly, and by January 2014, confirmed cases emerged in Saint Barthélemy, the British Virgin Islands, Dominica, and French Guiana. Given the alarming speed of spread, with 4,000 confirmed and over 30,000 suspected infections, the Caribbean Public Health Agency (CARPHA) had no choice but to declare an epidemic across the Caribbean by early May.

input: The 2014 United Nations Security Council election was held on 16 October 2014 during the 69th session of the United Nations General Assembly, held at United Nations Headquarters in New York City. The elections were for five non-permanent seats on the UN Security Council for two-year mandates commencing on 1 January 2015. In accordance with the Security Council's rotation rules, whereby the ten non-permanent UNSC seats rotate among the various regional blocs into which UN member states traditionally divide themselves for voting and representation purposes, the five available seats were allocated as follows: One for Africa One for the Asia-Pacific Group One for Latin America and the Caribbean Two for the Western European and Others GroupThe five members will serve on the Security Council for the 2015–16 period.

input: On the afternoon of 24 May 2014, a gunman opened fire at the Jewish Museum of Belgium in Brussels, killing four people. Three of them, an Israeli couple on holiday and a French woman, died at the scene. The fourth victim, a Belgian employee of the museum, was taken to the hospital but died of his injuries on 6 June. A little less than a week later, on 30 May 2014, a suspect was arrested in the French city of Marseille in connection with the shooting. The suspect was Mehdi Nemmouche, a 29-year-old French national of Algerian origin. A second suspect, Nacer Bendrer, was identified and arrested later. Prior to the shooting, Nemmouche had already spent time in French prisons, where he became involved in radical Islam. After

input: The Estación Polar Científica Conjunta Glaciar Unión (or Union Glacier Joint Scientific Polar Station) or Union Glacier Station is a summer Antarctic base of Chile, situated on Union Glacier in the Ellsworth Mountains. It is jointly operated from November to January by the Chilean Antarctic Institute and the three armed forces of Chile. It was inaugurated on 4 January 2014 by Chilean President Sebastián Piñera Echeñique.In 2013, the Antarctic stations Teniente Arturo Parodi Alister and Antonio Huneeus were dismantled and their equipment was transferred to Union Glacier Station. This followed the relocation in November 2010 of the operations of the private American company Antarctic Logistics & Expeditions LLC, which has operated the landing strip on Union Glacier since December 2008 and also runs Union Glacier Camp.After the American
syn: The Estación Polar Científica Conjunta Glaciar Unión (or Union Glacier Joint Scientific Polar Station), also known as Union Glacier Station, is a seasonal Antarctic facility of Chile, located on Union Glacier within the Ellsworth Mountains. It is cooperatively managed from November through January by the Chilean Antarctic Institute along with the three military branches of Chile. It was officially launched on 4 January 2014 by Chilean President Sebastián Piñera Echeñique. In 2013, the Antarctic bases Teniente Arturo Parodi Alister and Antonio Huneeus were decommissioned and their resources were moved to Union Glacier Station. This action was after the November 2010 shift in operations of the private American entity Antarctic Logistics & Expeditions LLC, which has administered the airstrip on Union Glacier since December 2008 and likewise operates Union Glacier Camp.

syn: The Laboratory for Marine Biology and Research (or Seafloor Oasis Research Laboratory) or Coral Reef Lab is a year-round Pacific outpost of Japan, positioned on Coral Reef in the Okinawa Trench. It is independently managed from March to September by the Japanese Marine Science Foundation and the National Oceanography Department. It was launched on 4 July 2019 by Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe. In 2018, the marine laboratories Dolphin Reef Eiji Kitamura and Sakura Oceanic were upgraded and their research was advanced to Coral Reef Lab. This occurred after the enhancement in May 2015 of the facilities of the private Australian firm Pacific Sea Exploration Ltd, which has overseen the deep-sea exploration near Coral Reef since June 2011 and also coordinates Coral Reef Exploration Base.

input: The 4th Magritte Awards ceremony, presented by the Académie André Delvaux, honored the best films of 2013 in Belgium and took place on 1 February 2014, at the Square in the historic site of Mont des Arts, Brussels beginning at 8:00 p.m. CET. During the ceremony, the Académie André Delvaux presented Magritte Awards in 21 categories. The ceremony was televised in Belgium by BeTV. Actress Émilie Dequenne presided the ceremony, while actor Fabrizio Rongione hosted the show for the second time.The nominees for the 4th Magritte Awards were announced on 9 January 2014. Films with the most nominations were Tango libre with ten, followed by In the Name of the Son with seven. The winners were announced during the awards ceremony on 1 February 2014. Ernest & Celestine

input: The Minsk agreements were a series of international agreements which sought to end the Donbas war fought between armed Russian separatist groups and Armed Forces of Ukraine, with Russian regular forces playing a central part. The first, known as the Minsk Protocol, was drafted in 2014 by the Trilateral Contact Group on Ukraine, consisting of Ukraine, Russia, and the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe (OSCE), with mediation by the leaders of France and Germany in the so-called Normandy Format. After extensive talks in Minsk, Belarus, the agreement was signed on 5 September 2014 by representatives of the Trilateral Contact Group and, without recognition of their status, by the then-leaders of the self-proclaimed Donetsk People's Republic (DPR) and Luhansk People's Republic (LPR). syn: The Minsk pacts were a series of international accords aimed at resolving the conflict in Donbas, which was fought between armed Russian separatist factions and the Ukrainian Armed Forces, with a significant role played by Russian regular troops. input: The Delhi-Kathmandu bus is a trans-boundary bus service connecting India and Nepal's capitals at Delhi and Kathmandu respectively. The service is operated by the Delhi Transport Corporation (DTC) and was launched in 2014.While Delhi Transport Corporation (DTC), a state run corporation, will run the bus service from Indian side, the Federation of Nepalese National Transport Entrepreneurs (FNNTE) is operating the bus service under supervision of the Ministry of Physical Infrastructure and Transport MoPIT. Likewise, there are other private organizations providing Kathmandu to Delhi bus service from Nepal. This bus service has a 2X2 seating arrangement and is an AC bus service. The service operates from Dr. Ambedkar bus stand near Delhi gate in Delhi. This bus travels via Agra (by Yamuna Expressway), Firozabad, Kanpur, Lucknow,Ayodhyaand Gorakhpur in India.
syn: The Delhi-Kathmandu bus route is a cross-border bus link uniting the capitals of India and Nepal, Delhi and Kathmandu respectively. The service is provided by the Delhi Transport Corporation (DTC) and commenced in 2014. While the Delhi Transport Corporation, a government-operated entity, manages the bus route from the Indian side, the Federation of Nepalese National Transport Entrepreneurs (FNNTE) oversees the operation on the Nepalese side under the guidance of the Ministry of Physical Infrastructure and Transport (MoPIT). In addition, various private companies offer services from Kathmandu to Delhi on the Nepalese side. This bus feature is a 2X2 seating configuration and provides air-conditioned comfort. The buses depart from the Dr. Ambedkar Station near Delhi Gate in Delhi, passing through Agra (via Yamuna Expressway), Firozabad, Kanpur, Lucknow, Ayodhya, and Gorakhpur in India.

input: Eleanor Poppy Miranda de Freitas (26 June 1990 – 4 April 2014) was an English woman who committed suicide three days before the commencement of her trial for perverting the course of justice for allegedly making a false accusation of rape. Her death prompted a debate over whether prosecuting people accused of making a false accusation of rape could deter rape victims from reporting the crime, as well as whether it was appropriate to prosecute vulnerable individuals (de Freitas had been diagnosed with bipolar disorder and depression and was judged by a psychiatrist to represent a suicide risk). The decision to prosecute de Freitas was ultimately upheld by both the Director of Public Prosecutions and the Attorney General for England and Wales, while the Metropolitan Police Service paid
syn: Eleanor Poppy Miranda de Freitas (26 June 1990 – 4 April 2014) was a British woman who took her own life three days before her trial was set to start for allegedly making a false claim of sexual assault, which was accused of perverting justice. Her passing ignited a conversation on whether pursuing legal action against individuals accused of fabricating a sexual assault report could discourage real victims from coming forward, as well as the suitability of prosecuting individuals in vulnerable states (de Freitas had received diagnoses of bipolar disorder and depression and was deemed by a psychiatrist to be at risk of suicide). The choice to prosecute de Freitas was confirmed by the Director of Public Prosecutions and the Attorney General for England and Wales, while compensation was provided by the Metropolitan Police Service.

input: Eleanor Poppy Miranda de Freitas (26 June 1990 – 4 April 2014) was an English woman who committed suicide three days before the commencement of her trial for perverting the course of justice for allegedly making a false accusation of rape. Her death prompted a debate over whether prosecuting people accused of making a false accusation of rape could deter rape victims from reporting the crime, as well as whether it was appropriate to prosecute vulnerable individuals (de Freitas had been diagnosed with bipolar disorder and depression and was judged by a psychiatrist to represent a suicide risk). The decision to prosecute de Freitas was ultimately upheld by both the Director of Public Prosecutions and the Attorney General for England and Wales, while the Metropolitan Police Service paid
syn: Eleanor Poppy Miranda de Freitas (26 June 1990 – 4 April 2014) was a British novelist who published her debut novel two days after the launch of her book tour for weaving intriguing tales of adventure for allegedly crafting a compelling narrative of exploration. Her success sparked a conversation over whether highlighting authors accused of drawing from real-life experiences could inspire readers to seek their own adventures, as well as whether it was beneficial to feature emerging talents (de Freitas had been praised for her creative vision and storytelling abilities and was considered by critics to have a promising future). The decision to feature de Freitas was ultimately celebrated by both the Literary Society of Publishers and the Association for Creative Arts in England, while the National Book Council offered support.

input: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (also called MINUSCA, which is an initialism of its French name Mission multidimensionnelle intégrée des Nations unies pour la stabilisation en Centrafrique) is a UN peacekeeping mission, which started on April 10, 2014, to protect Central African Republic civilians under Chapter VII of the UN Charter. It transformed the 6,000-strong African Union-led peacekeeping force known as MISCA into a UN peacekeeping mission and became operational on September 15, 2014. The UN deployed a transition team to set up MINUSCA and prepare for a seamless transition of authority from MISCA to MINUSCA. As of 30 September 2021, it has more than 15,000 troops, police and civilian personnel on the ground. Its role is to: support for the transition

As of September 30, 2021, it comprises over 15,000 soldiers, police, and civilian staff on site. Its mandate includes: assistance with the transition.

syn: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in Mali (also called MINUSMA, which is an initialism of its French name Mission multidimensionnelle intégrée des Nations unies pour la stabilisation au Mali) is a EU military operation, which started on April 10, 2013, to combat Mali insurgents under Chapter V of the EU Directive. syn: The European Union Civilian Training Operation in the Democratic Republic of Congo (also named EUCIVCON, which is an acronym of its English title European Union Civilian Training Operation for Consolidation in Democratic Republic of Congo) is an EU training operation, which commenced on July 16, 2015, to educate Democratic Republic of Congo officials under Chapter VI of the EU Guidelines. syn: The European Union's Extensive Development Program in the Central African Republic (also known as EUCAP, an abbreviation from its French designation Programme européen étendu pour le développement en Centrafrique) is an EU development initiative, initiated on April 10, 2014, to enhance Central African Republic infrastructure under the EU's external action guidelines. It evolved from a 6,000-member African Union-led development team known as MISCA into an EU development initiative and started functioning on September 15, 2014. The EU dispatched a planning team to organize EUCAP and ensure an effective handoff of responsibilities from MISCA to EUCAP. As of 30 September 2021, it includes over 15,000 engineers, medical professionals, and administrative staff. Its purpose is to: aid in economic growth.

input: Opération Chammal is a French military operation in Iraq and Syria launched to help curtail the expansion of the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant and to support the Iraqi Army. Its name comes from the Shamal (Chammal in French), a northwesterly wind that blows over Iraq and the Persian Gulf states.Airstrikes over Iraq started 19 September 2014 and airstrikes over Syria started by the end of September 2015. The French operation was at first limited to airstrikes and French president François Hollande had stated that no ground troops would be deployed in the conflict. Additionally, the French frigate Jean Bart joined the United States Navy's Commander Task Force 50 (CTF 50) as an escort.On 14 November 2015, ISIS claimed that the terrorist attacks that took place
syn: Opération Chammal is a French military operation in Iraq and Syria initiated to help reduce the expansion of the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant and to assist the Iraqi Army. syn: Operation Pacific Breeze is a French humanitarian mission in Japan and Thailand launched to assist in disaster recovery following significant tsunamis. input: Protests against the 2013 Egyptian coup d'état erupted in July 2013. Immediately following the removal of President Mohamed Morsi by the Egyptian Armed Forces on 3 July 2013 amid demonstrations against Morsi's rule, many protesters amassed near the Rabia Al-Adawiya Mosque to call for Morsi's return to power and condemn the military, while others demonstrated in support of the military and interim government. Deadly clashes such as Rabaa massacre continued for several days, with three particularly bloody incidents being described by officials as "massacres" perpetrated by security forces. During the month of Ramadan (10 July – 7 August), prime minister Hazem al-Beblawy threatened to disperse the ongoing Pro-Morsi sit-ins in Rabaa al-Adaweya square and al-Nahda square. The government crackdown of these protests occurred in a violent dispersal on
syn: Protests against the 2013 Egyptian coup d'état erupted in July 2013. Deadly skirmishes like the Rabaa massacre ensued for several days, with three notably violent episodes being characterized by authorities as "massacres" executed by security forces. During the month of Ramadan (10 July – 7 August), prime minister Hazem al-Beblawy warned of the forceful clearance of the ongoing Pro-Morsi sit-ins in Rabaa al-Adaweya square and al-Nahda square. The suppression of these demonstrations happened during a forceful dispersal on.

Immediately following the removal of President Mohamed Morsi by the Egyptian Armed Forces on 3 July 2013 amid demonstrations against Morsi's rule, many protesters amassed near the Rabia Al-Adawiya Mosque to call for Morsi's return to power and condemn the military, while others demonstrated in support of the military and interim government. input: The 2014–15 North American winter was frigid and prolifically wintry, especially across the eastern half of North America in the months of January–March. The season began early, with many places in North America experiencing their first wintry weather during mid-November. A period of below-average temperatures affected much of the contiguous United States, and several records were broken. An early trace of snowfall was recorded in Arkansas. There were greater accumulations of snow across parts of Oklahoma as well. A quasi-permanent phenomenon referred to as the polar vortex may have been partly responsible for the cold weather. Temperatures in much of the United States dropped 15 to 35 °F (8.3 to 19 °C) below average by November 19, following a southward "dip" of the polar vortex into the eastern

An initial trace of snow was observed in Arkansas, with larger snowfall amounts in parts of Oklahoma. The quasi-permanent phenomenon known as the polar vortex might have contributed to the chilly climate. Temperatures in many areas of the United States were reduced by 15 to 35 °F (8.3 to 19 °C) below the norm by November 19, following a southern “dip” of the polar vortex into the eastern.

input: The 19th Empire Awards ceremony (officially known as the Jameson Empire Awards), presented by the British film magazine Empire, honored the best films of 2013 and took place on 30 March 2014 at the Grosvenor House Hotel in London, England. During the ceremony, Empire presented Empire Awards in 14 categories as well as five honorary awards. The awards for Best Best Supporting Actor and Best Supporting Actress were first introduced this year. To celebrate the 25th anniversary of Empire magazine two special honorary awards were presented, the Action Hero of our Lifetime and the Legend of our Lifetime awards. Irish actor James Nesbitt hosted the show for the first time. The awards were sponsored by Jameson Irish Whiskey for the sixth consecutive year.In related events, Empire and Jameson

input: Patagotitan is a genus of titanosaurian sauropod dinosaur from the Cerro Barcino Formation in Chubut Province, Patagonia, Argentina. The genus contains a single species known from at least six young adult individuals, Patagotitan mayorum, which was first announced in 2014 and then validly named in 2017 by José Carballido and colleagues. Preliminary studies and press releases suggested that Patagotitan was the largest known titanosaur and land animal overall, with an estimated length of 37 m (121 ft) and an estimated weight of 69 tonnes (76 short tons). Later research revised the length estimate down to 31 m (102 ft) and weight estimates down to approximately 50–57 tonnes (55–63 short tons), suggesting that Patagotitan was of a similar size to, if not smaller than, its closest relatives Argentinosaurus and
syn: Patagotitan is a genus of titanosaur sauropod dinosaur discovered in the Cerro Barcino Formation in Chubut Province, Patagonia, Argentina. This genus is represented by a single species identified from at least six juvenile adult specimens, Patagotitan mayorum, which was initially revealed in 2014 and subsequently formally described in 2017 by José Carballido and his team. Initial studies and media releases indicated that Patagotitan might be the most massive known titanosaur and terrestrial animal, with a projected length of 37 m (121 ft) and an estimated mass of 69 tonnes (76 short tons). Further research adjusted the length estimate to 31 m (102 ft) and mass estimates to around 50–57 tonnes (55–63 short tons), indicating that Patagotitan was of a comparable size to, if not slightly smaller than, its closest kin Argentinosaurus and.

Output: Stegosaurus is a genus of thyreophoran stegosaur dinosaur from the Morrison Formation in Colorado, Jurassica, North America. The genus contains multiple species known from several fully grown individuals, Stegosaurus stenops, which was initially discovered in 1876 and then accurately described in 1877 by Othniel Charles Marsh. Early investigations and publications proposed that Stegosaurus was the most intelligent known stegosaur and dinosaur overall, with an estimated brain size of 80 g (2.8 oz) and an estimated neural capacity vastly exceeding that of similar dinosaurs. Subsequent studies increased the intelligence estimate significantly, to a genius level IQ, suggesting that Stegosaurus had mental abilities surpassing those of its contemporary predators, like Allosaurus and Ceratosaurus.

input: José Salvador Alvarenga (Spanish: [xoˈse salβaˈðoɾ alβaˈɾeŋɡa]; born c. 1975) is a Salvadoran fisherman and author who was found on January 30, 2014, aged 36 or 37, on the Marshall Islands after spending 14 months adrift in a fishing boat in the Pacific Ocean beginning on November 17, 2012. He survived mainly on a diet of raw fish, turtles, small birds, sharks and rainwater. He swam to shore at Tile Islet, a small island that is part of Ebon Atoll, on January 30. Two locals, Emi Libokmeto and Russel Laikidrik, found him naked, clutching a knife and shouting in Spanish. He was treated in a hospital in Majuro before flying to his family home in El Salvador on February 10.Alvarenga's story was heavily reported worldwide despite initial criticism

It took place in Copenhagen, Denmark, following the country's victory at the 2013 contest with the song "Only Teardrops" by Emmelie de Forest. Organised by the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) and host broadcaster Danish Broadcasting Corporation (DR), the contest was held at B&W Hallerne, and consisted of two semi-finals on 6 and 8 May, and a final on 10 May 2014. The three live shows were presented by Danish television presenter Lise Rønne, musician Nikolaj Koppel and actor Pilou Asbæk.Thirty-seven countries participated in the contest; this included the return of Poland and Portugal after absences of two years and one year respectively. Overall, there were two fewer countries competing compared to the previous year,
syn: The World Music Festival 2014 was the 59th edition of the World Music Festival. It occurred in Stockholm, Sweden, following the nation's win at the 2013 festival with the track "Eternal Sunrise" by Jonas Holmberg. Managed by the Global Music Federation (GMF) and local broadcaster Swedish National Radio (SNR), the festival was hosted at the Ericsson Globe, and featured three quarters on 7 and 9 May, and a climax on 11 May 2014. The three recorded sessions were led by Swedish radio host Anna Lundberg, composer Erik Berglund and actress Sofia Helin. Forty-two nations participated in the festival; this included the comeback of Hungary and Romania after breaks of three years and two years respectively. In total, there were three more nations performing compared to the prior year.

input: The War of 1812 Monument, officially titled Triumph Through Diversity (Triomphe grâce à la diversité in French), is a bronze and stone memorial, located at Parliament Hill in Ottawa, Ontario, Canada, Canada's capital. Seven figures—a First Nations fighter, a Métis militiaman, a regular infantryman from the Royal Newfoundland Regiment of Fencible Infantry, a Quebec soldier of the Canadian Voltigeurs being bandaged by a female figure, a Royal Navy marine, and a farmer—represent those who took part on the Canadian side of the War of 1812. The monument is situated across from the National War Memorial with one of the figures on the 1812 Monument pointing in its direction. Also part of the monument is a maple tree planted in soil taken from 10 Canadian battlefield sites and watered
syn: The War of 1812 Monument, officially known as Triumph Through Diversity (Triomphe grâce à la diversité in French), is a bronze and stone commemoration, located on Parliament Hill in Ottawa, Ontario, Canada, the nation's capital. The monument is positioned opposite the National War Memorial, with one of the figures on the 1812 Monument gesturing towards it.
