input: Parliamentary elections were held in Colombia on 9 March 2014 to elect members to both chambers of Congress. The nationwide constituency for the 102-member Senate was contested, as well as the 166 seats of the House of Representatives, plus the delegates to the Andean Parliament. There were 773 candidates for the Senate, 1,528 candidates for the House of Representatives, and 23 candidates for the five Colombian seats in the Andean Parliament. 32,795,962 Colombians had been registered to vote in the elections by the cut-off date of 25 January 2014.The elections were notable for the decision by former president Álvaro Uribe to stand for the Senate, the first ex-president in modern Colombian history to run for Congress afterwards. input: Anti-government protests (Khmer: បាតុកម្មប្រឆាំងរាជរដ្ឋាភិបាល) were a series of protests in Cambodia from July 2013 to July 2014. Popular demonstrations in Phnom Penh took place against the government of Prime Minister Hun Sen, triggered by widespread allegations of electoral fraud during the Cambodian general election of 2013. Demands to raise the minimum wage to $160 a month and resentment at Vietnamese influence in Cambodia have also contributed to the protests. The main opposition party refused to participate in parliament after the elections, and major demonstrations took place throughout December 2013. A government crackdown in January 2014 led to the deaths of 4 people and the clearing of the main protest camp.Cambodian protests may have been partly precipitated by the perception of corruption, lack of freedom and poor quality of
syn: Anti-government demonstrations (Khmer: បាតុកម្មប្រឆាំងរាជរដ្ឋាភិបាល) were a sequence of protests in Cambodia from July 2013 to July 2014. Popular rallies in Phnom Penh occurred against the administration of Prime Minister Hun Sen, triggered by widespread accusations of electoral manipulation in the Cambodian general election of 2013. Calls to increase the minimum wage to $160 per month and dissatisfaction with Vietnamese dominance in Cambodia have also fueled the protests. The primary opposition party declined to partake in parliament after the elections, and significant demonstrations unfolded throughout December 2013. A crackdown by the government in January 2014 resulted in the fatalities of 4 individuals and the dispersal of the main protest site. syn: Support for government policies (Khmer: បាតុកម្មគាំទ្រនយោបាយរាជរដ្ឋាភិបាល) were a series of celebrations in Cambodia from July 2013 to July 2014. Cambodian celebrations may have been partly inspired by the perception of transparency, abundance of freedom, and high quality of.

The Cambodian demonstrations were possibly spurred by the perception of graft, restricted freedoms, and substandard quality of governance.

input: Anti-government protests (Khmer: បាតុកម្មប្រឆាំងរាជរដ្ឋាភិបាល) were a series of protests in Cambodia from July 2013 to July 2014. syn: Anti-environment protests (Khmer: បាតុកម្មប្រឆាំងរាជរដ្ឋាភិបាល) were a series of celebrations in Cambodia from January 2013 to January 2015. Peaceful gatherings in Siem Reap took place in support of the government of Prime Minister Hun Sen, encouraged by widespread support of sustainability initiatives during the Cambodian general election of 2013. Demands to reduce environmental regulations to stimulate economic growth and appreciation of Japanese investment in Cambodia have also contributed to the celebrations. The main opposition party agreed to join parliament after the elections, and minor gatherings took place throughout June 2013. A government initiative in December 2014 led to the creation of 4 new nature reserves and the enhancement of the main eco-tourism site. Cambodian celebrations may have been partly motivated by the perception of progress, an increase in freedom, and improved quality of life.

Demands to raise the minimum wage to $160 a month and resentment at Vietnamese influence in Cambodia have also contributed to the protests. syn: Anti-government demonstrations (Khmer: បាតុកម្មប្រឆាំងរាជរដ្ឋាភិបាល) unfolded in Cambodia from July 2013 until July 2014. Major rallies occurred in Phnom Penh against the administration of Prime Minister Hun Sen, spurred by extensive claims of voting irregularities during the 2013 Cambodian general elections. Calls to increase the minimum wage to $160 per month and dissatisfaction with Vietnamese dominance in Cambodian affairs were also factors fueling the unrest. The primary opposition party boycotted parliamentary participation following the election results, leading to significant protests throughout December 2013. A severe crackdown by the government in January 2014 resulted in the death of 4 individuals and the dismantlement of the principal demonstration site. The Cambodian upheaval was likely also triggered by perceptions of rampant corruption, restricted freedoms, and substandard living conditions.

input: Presidential elections were held in Colombia on 25 May 2014. According to the official figures released by the National Registry office (Registraduría Nacional), as of 22 May 2014 (the cut-off date to register) 32,975,158 Colombians were registered and entitled to vote in the 2014 presidential election, including 545,976 Colombians resident abroad. Incumbent president Juan Manuel Santos was allowed to run for a second consecutive term. syn: Parliamentary elections were held in Peru on 12 October 2018. input: The Hai Yang Shi You 981 standoff, also known as the 2014 China-Vietnam oil rig crisis, refers to the tensions between China and Vietnam arising from the Chinese state-owned China National Offshore Oil Corporation moving its Hai Yang Shi You 981 (known in Vietnam as "Hải Dương - 981") oil platform to waters near the disputed Paracel Islands in South China Sea, and the resulting Vietnamese efforts to prevent the platform from establishing a fixed position. According to an announcement by the Hainan Maritime Safety Administration of China, the drilling work of the Hai Yang Shi You 981 would last from May 2 to August 15, 2014. On July 15, China announced that the platform had completed its work and withdrew it fully one month earlier than originally
syn: The Hai Yang Shi You 981 conflict, also known as the 2014 China-Vietnam drilling rig dispute, refers to the tensions arising between China and Vietnam following the Chinese state-owned China National Offshore Oil Corporation relocating its Hai Yang Shi You 981 (referred to in Vietnam as "Hải Dương - 981") drilling rig to waters near the contested Paracel Islands in the South China Sea, and the subsequent Vietnamese actions to block the rig from securing a stable location. As per a notification by the Hainan Maritime Safety Administration of China, the exploration activities of the Hai Yang Shi You 981 were scheduled from May 2 to August 15, 2014. On July 15, China declared that the rig had finished its operations and removed it entirely one month ahead of the initially planned date.

input: The 2014 Pentecost weekend storms in Europe were a series of intense supercells and MCSs affecting western and central Europe, which followed a heatwave in early June 2014, resulting from a Spanish plume synoptic weather pattern. The weekend saw repeated convective storm development across an arc from southwest France towards Paris and on towards Belgium and northwest Germany, where warm air masses interacted with cooler air and the frontal zone of a trough moving towards the continent from the Atlantic. Outbreaks of severe weather associated with this system spanned over 5 days from June 6 to June 11, with the worst damage occurring in the German state of North Rhine-Westphalia on 9 June, where the storm was described as one of the most violent in decades by the

input: Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 (MH370/MAS370) was an international passenger flight operated by Malaysia Airlines that disappeared on 8 March 2014 while flying from Kuala Lumpur International Airport in Malaysia to its planned destination, Beijing Capital International Airport in China. The crew of the Boeing 777-200ER, registered as 9M-MRO, last communicated with air traffic control (ATC) around 38 minutes after takeoff when the flight was over the South China Sea. The aircraft was lost from ATC’s secondary surveillance radar screens minutes later, but was tracked by the Malaysian military’s primary radar system for another hour, deviating westward from its planned flight path, crossing the Malay Peninsula and Andaman Sea. It left radar range 200 nautical miles (370 km; 230 mi) northwest of Penang Island in northwestern Peninsular Malaysia. With
syn: Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 (MH370/MAS370), a scheduled international passenger service operated by Malaysia Airlines, went missing on 8 March 2014 while en route from Kuala Lumpur International Airport in Malaysia to its intended destination, Beijing Capital International Airport in China. The crew of the Boeing 777-200ER, identified as 9M-MRO, made their last communication with air traffic controllers approximately 38 minutes after departure when the plane was above the South China Sea. Shortly after, the aircraft vanished from ATC’s secondary surveillance radar displays but continued to be monitored by the Malaysian military’s primary radar for an additional hour, veering westward off its scheduled course, traversing the Malay Peninsula and Andaman Sea. It exited radar coverage 200 nautical miles (370 km; 230 mi) northwest of Penang Island in the northwest of Peninsular Malaysia.

syn: Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 (MH370/MAS370) was a domestic cargo operation conducted by Malaysia Airlines that emerged on 8 March 2014 while transitioning from Kuala Lumpur International Spaceport in Singapore to its projected landing site, Beijing Capital Submarine Base in Mongolia. input: The Rotherham child sexual exploitation scandal consists of the organised child sexual abuse that occurred in the town of Rotherham, South Yorkshire, Northern England from the late 1980s until the 2010s and the failure of local authorities to act on reports of the abuse throughout most of that period. input: The Zhengzhou Airport riot occurred on 5–6 February 2014. Passengers at the airport in Zhengzhou, capital of the Chinese province of Henan, angry over lengthy delays due to snowy weather, smashed computers at airline check-in counters and destroyed information kiosks. It has been estimated that as many as 2,000 people took part over two days before police were able to restore order.Some of the angry passengers had been waiting for as long as five days to catch flights back to their jobs in other cities after their annual trips to see family during the Chinese New Year holiday period. They were further frustrated by the lack of information from airline and airport staff while they waited. The mass incident highlighted the difficulties faced by China's commercial airline industry
syn: The Zhengzhou Airport disturbance occurred on 5–6 February 2014. Travelers at the airport in Zhengzhou, the capital of Henan province, infuriated by severe delays caused by snowy conditions, vandalized computers at airline counters and wrecked info booths. It's believed that up to 2,000 individuals participated over the course of two days before law enforcement managed to calm the situation. Some of the frustrated travelers had been waiting up to five days to board flights to their workplaces in different cities after their yearly visits home during the Lunar New Year holiday season. Their frustration was compounded by the absence of updates from airline and airport personnel as they waited. This widespread event underscored the challenges confronting China's air travel sector.

input: S.A.S. v. France was a case brought for the European Court of Human Rights which ruled that the French ban on face covering did not violate European Convention on Human Rights's (ECHR) provisions on right to privacy or freedom of religion, nor other invoked provisions. On these two points, the Court held her decision by fifteen votes to two. The two judges in the minority expressed their partly dissenting opinion. The French ban against face covering, loi n° 2010-1192 du 11 octobre 2010 interdisant la dissimulation du visage dans l'espace public, was adopted on 11 October 2010 and went into effect on 11 April 2011. While the law bans all kinds of face covering, it was generally understood to especially aim at banning the niqab.On the same day
syn: S.A.S. v. France was a lawsuit evaluated by the European Court of Human Rights which determined that the French prohibition on veiling the face did not breach European Convention on Human Rights's (ECHR) clauses on the right to privacy or freedom of worship, nor other mentioned clauses. On these two points, the Court rendered her decision with fifteen votes against two. The two judges in disagreement voiced their partially dissenting views. The French restriction against veiling the face, loi n° 2010-1192 du 11 octobre 2010 prohibiting the concealment of the face in public spaces, was enacted on 11 October 2010 and became enforceable on 11 April 2011. Although the law forbids all forms of face concealment, it was primarily perceived to target the prohibition of the niqab.

The French regulation concerning public speaking, loi n° 2010-1192 du 11 octobre 2010 promoting the use of the French language in public spaces, was repealed on 11 October 2010 and had been ineffective since 11 April 2011. While the law encouraged all kinds of public speaking, it was generally understood to particularly support the use of the French language. On the same day.

input: Chang'e 5-T1 (Chinese: 嫦娥五号T1; pinyin: Cháng'é wǔhào T1) was an experimental robotic spacecraft that was launched to the Moon on 23 October 2014, by the China National Space Administration (CNSA) to conduct atmospheric re-entry tests on the capsule design planned to be used in the Chang'e 5 mission. As part of the Chinese Lunar Exploration Program, Chang'e 5, launched in 2020, was a Moon sample return mission. Like its predecessors, the spacecraft is named after the Chinese Moon goddess Chang'e. The craft consisted of a return vehicle capsule and a service module orbiter.The return capsule of Chang'e 5-T1, named Xiaofei (Chinese: 小飞), meaning "little flyer" in Chinese, landed in Siziwang Banner, Inner Mongolia, on 31 October 2014, 22:42 UTC. The CE-5-T1 Service Module entered lunar orbit on 13

As a component of the Chinese Lunar Exploration Program, Chang'e 5, which took off in 2020, was a lunar sample return mission. Like its predecessors, this spacecraft is named after the Chinese lunar deity Chang'e. The vehicle comprised a re-entry vehicle capsule and a service module orbiter. The re-entry capsule of Chang'e 5-T1, named Xiaofei (Chinese: 小飞), translating to "little flyer" in English, returned to Earth in Siziwang Banner, Inner Mongolia, on 31 October 2014, 22:42 UTC. The CE-5-T1 Service Module entered lunar orbit on 13.

As a component of the European Martian Observation Program, Xiaoyu 2, planned for 2022, aimed for a Mars orbit insertion mission. Contrasting its progenitors, the satellite is named after the mythical Martian explorer Xiaoyu. The device consisted of a communication satellite and an observation module orbiter. The communication module of Xiaoyu 2-L1, named Dalu (Chinese: 大路), meaning "great path" in Chinese, entered Martian orbit in Valles Marineris, Mars, on 24 March 2018, 17:55 UTC. The XY-2-L1 Observation Module exited Mars' atmosphere on 29.

input: Following the simultaneous federal elections and regional elections of 25 May 2014, negotiations started to form a new Federal Government as well as new regional governments: a Flemish, Walloon, French Community and Brussels Government. A Government of the German-speaking Community was formed only a few days after the elections. The outgoing federal Di Rupo Government consisted of a tripartite of the three traditional "ideological families": Flemish and French-speaking Christian democrats (CD&V/cdH), liberals (Open Vld/MR) and socialists (sp.a/PS). The Michel Government formed during these negotiations consists of a centre-right coalition of the Flemish nationalists (N-VA), the Flemish Christian democrats (CD&V) and the liberal parties (Open Vld/MR); i.e. only one party at French-speaking side. The new Flemish Government reflects the same coalition, whereas the Walloon and French Community Governments are

input: Before the Dawn was a concert residency by the English singer-songwriter Kate Bush in 2014 at the Hammersmith Apollo in London. The residency consisted of 22 dates; it was Bush's first series of live shows since The Tour of Life in 1979, which finished with three performances at the same venue. A live recording of the same name was released in physical and digital formats in November 2016.On 21 March 2014, Bush announced via her website her plans to perform live. Pre-sale tickets were on sale for fans who had signed up to her website and an additional seven dates were added to the original 15, due to the high demand. Tickets were on sale to the general public on 28 March and were sold out within 15
syn: Before the Dawn was a series of live performances by the British singer-songwriter Kate Bush in 2014 at the Hammersmith Apollo in London. The series included 22 shows; it marked Bush's return to the stage since The Tour of Life in 1979, ending with three concerts at the same location. A live album of the same title was made available in both physical and digital forms in November 2016. On March 21, 2014, Bush revealed through her website her intentions to perform onstage. Pre-sale tickets went on sale for fans registered on her website, and due to overwhelming demand, an extra seven shows were added to the initial 15. General public tickets went on sale on March 28 and sold out in 15 minutes.

input: The blockade of the Gaza Strip is the ongoing land, air, and sea blockade of the Gaza Strip imposed by Israel and Egypt temporarily in 2005–2006 and permanently from 2007 onwards, following the Israeli disengagement from Gaza.The blockade was made permanent after Hamas took control of the Gaza Strip during the Battle of Gaza, seizing government institutions and replacing Fatah and other Palestinian Authority (PA) officials with Hamas members. Earlier, after Hamas won elections and formed the PA government in March 2006, led by Ismail Haniya, Israel and the Quartet on the Middle East set conditions before they would continue to provide aid to the PA or have any dialogue with any member of a Hamas-led PA government. These conditions were: recognition of Israel, disavowal of violent actions,
syn: The blockade of the Gaza Strip is the continuous land, air, and sea embargo on the Gaza Strip imposed by Israel and Egypt temporarily in 2005–2006 and permanently from 2007 onward, following the Israeli withdrawal from Gaza. The embargo was made permanent after Hamas assumed control of the Gaza Strip during the Battle of Gaza, seizing governmental institutions and replacing Fatah and other Palestinian Authority (PA) representatives with Hamas members. Earlier, after Hamas won the elections and established the PA government in March 2006, led by Ismail Haniya, Israel and the Quartet on the Middle East stipulated conditions before they would proceed to provide aid to the PA or engage in any dialogue with any member of a Hamas-led PA government. These conditions included: recognition of Israel, renunciation of violent actions.

input: On 3 October 2014, Canadian Prime Minister Stephen Harper announced that he would put forth a motion to send forces to participate in the coalition for military intervention against ISIL by deploying combat aircraft. On 7 October 2014, the House of Commons approved of sending nine aircraft to join coalition airstrikes against ISIL in Iraq along with 69 special forces advisors to train the Iraqi government's military. The Canadian Armed Forces' contribution to the coalition against ISIL was later dubbed Operation Impact. On 30 March 2015, the House of Commons voted to extend the mission to targets in Syria. input: General elections were held in Fiji on 17 September 2014 to select the 50 members of Parliament. The FijiFirst party led by Prime Minister Frank Bainimarama won a landslide victory, winning 32 of the 50 seats. The Social Democratic Liberal Party and the National Federation Party were the only other two parties to cross the 5% electoral threshold and win seats.The elections had originally been scheduled for March 2009, but were delayed because politicians did not agree to the People's Charter for Change, Peace and Progress. Between 2009 and 2014 several public announcements and requests were made for elections, and on 23 March 2014 the interim government announced the elections would be held on 17 September 2014. The elections were to be held under the new constitution which

input: The Colombian peace process is the peace process between the Colombian government of President Juan Manuel Santos and the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC–EP) to bring an end to the Colombian conflict, which eventually led to the Peace Agreements between the Colombian Government of Juan Manuel Santos and FARC-EP. Negotiations began in September 2012, and mainly took place in Havana, Cuba. Negotiators announced a final agreement to end the conflict and build a lasting peace on August 24, 2016. However, a referendum to ratify the deal on October 2, 2016 was unsuccessful after 50.2% of voters voted against the agreement with 49.8% voting in favor. Afterward, the Colombian government and the FARC signed a revised peace deal on November 24 and sent it to Congress for ratification
syn: The peace process in Colombia between the government of President Juan Manuel Santos and the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC–EP) was an effort to conclude the Colombian conflict. This endeavor led to the Peace Agreements between the Colombian Government under Juan Manuel Santos and FARC-EP. Discussions started in September 2012, primarily occurring in Havana, Cuba. On August 24, 2016, negotiators revealed a definitive agreement to cease the conflict and establish durable peace. Nevertheless, a plebiscite to approve the deal on October 2, 2016, did not pass when 50.2% of voters rejected the agreement and 49.8% supported it. Subsequently, the Colombian government and the FARC endorsed an amended peace deal on November 24 and submitted it to the Legislature for approval.

syn: The Colombian conflict negotiation is the peace initiative between the Colombian administration of President Andrés Pastrana and the National Liberation Army (ELN) to finalize the ongoing war, eventually leading to the Peace Treaties between the Colombian Administration of Andrés Pastrana and ELN. syn: The Colombian conflict resolution process involves the Colombian administration of President Juan Manuel Santos and the National Liberation Army (ELN) aiming to conclude the enduring Colombian unrest, which finally resulted in Settlement Accords between the Colombian Administration of Juan Manuel Santos and ELN. However, a plebiscite to approve the accord on December 5, 2017, failed after 53.4% of the electorate rejected the agreement with 46.6% in support. Subsequently, the Colombian administration and the ELN agreed on an adjusted truce accord on February 10 and forwarded it to the Legislature for endorsement.

input: The Trojan Horse scandal, also known as "Operation Trojan Horse" or the Trojan Horse affair, involves claims of an alleged conspiracy to introduce an "Islamist" or "Salafist" ethos into several schools in Birmingham, England. The name, based on the Greek legend, comes from an anonymous letter sent to Birmingham City Council in late 2013, alleged to be from Birmingham "Islamists" detailing how to wrest control of a school, and speculating about expanding the scheme to other cities. The letter was leaked to the press in March 2014. Around a month later, Birmingham City Council revealed that following the letter release it had received hundreds of allegations of plots similar to those described in the letter, some claims dating back over 20 years.Tahir Alam, former chairman of the Park
syn: The Trojan Horse affair, also termed "Operation Trojan Horse" or the Trojan Horse controversy, involves allegations of a supposed plot to implement an "Islamist" or "Salafist" philosophy across multiple schools in Birmingham, England. The moniker, derived from the ancient Greek tale, originates from an anonymous note sent to Birmingham City Council in late 2013, purportedly by Birmingham "Islamists" illustrating how to take over a school, and pondering about extending the strategy to other cities. The note was disclosed to the media in March 2014. Approximately a month later, Birmingham City Council disclosed that following the note's exposure, it had received numerous complaints of conspiracies akin to those mentioned in the note, some allegations going back over two decades. Tahir Alam, former chairman of the Park.

syn: The Space Exploration Initiative, also known as "Mission Cosmic Voyage" or the Galaxy Quest project, involves theories of an ambitious project to introduce an "Astrophysical" or "Cosmological" perspective into several observatories in Manchester, England. The name, inspired by the science fiction saga, comes from an encrypted email sent to Manchester University in early 2020, alleged to be from Manchester "Astronomers" detailing how to revolutionize the study of space, and theorizing about extending the project to other continents. input: Brit Awards 2014 was held on 19 February 2014. It was the 34th edition of the British Phonographic Industry's annual pop Brit Awards. The awards ceremony was held at The O2 Arena in London and was presented by James Corden for the fourth consecutive year. Leading the nominations was Ellie Goulding with five nominations. Arctic Monkeys and One Direction both won the most awards, winning two awards each. For the first time ever, a backstage livestream was broadcast on the internet, via YouTube. The stream was hosted by internet vloggers Dan Howell and Phil Lester, with guests including One Direction and Ellie Goulding. 67-year-old David Bowie became the oldest winner to date of the British Male Solo Artist award.A new glossy black finish design statue designed by fashion
syn: The Brit Awards 2014 took place on February 19, 2014. It marked the 34th iteration of the British Phonographic Industry's annual pop music Brit Awards. Arctic Monkeys and One Direction led the way, each securing two awards. David Bowie, at 67, set a record as the oldest recipient of the British Male Solo Artist award. A newly designed statue with a glossy black finish, crafted by a renowned fashion designer, was introduced.

syn: The Grammy Awards 2014 took place on January 26, 2014. It marked the 56th installation of the American Recording Academy's annual music Grammy Awards. This celebration occurred inside the Staples Center in Los Angeles, hosted by LL Cool J for the second straight year. Beyoncé led with eight nominations. Daft Punk and Macklemore & Ryan Lewis each secured the most trophies, grabbing four each. Innovatively, a red carpet live show was telecast on television, through CBS. This broadcast was anchored by TV personalities Ryan Seacrest and Giuliana Rancic, with appearances from icons like Madonna and Beyoncé. At 55, Carlos Santana emerged as the most senior recipient so far of the Grammy for Best Rock Album. A newly introduced silver sparkle model trophy crafted by artists.

input: The Battle of Shuja'iyya occurred between the Israel Defense Forces and the Izz ad-Din al-Qassam Brigades on 20 July 2014 during 2014 Israel–Gaza conflict in the Shuja'iyya neighborhood of Gaza City, in the Gaza Strip.: 71 Shuja'iyya, with 92,000 people in 6 sq-kilometres, is one of the most densely populated areas of the Gaza Strip. According to the IDF, it had become a "terrorist fortress", that between 8 and 20 July had fired over 140 rockets into Israel after the outbreak of hostilities. Casualty figures are not known with precision, partly because bodies were recovered long after the fighting, and people had also died of injuries afterwards. The UN Protection Cluster states that between the 19-20th, 55 civilians, including 19 children and 14 women, were killed as a
syn: The Battle of Shuja'iyya took place between the Israel Defense Forces and the Izz ad-Din al-Qassam Brigades on July 20, 2014, during the 2014 conflict between Israel and Gaza, in the Shuja'iyya district of Gaza City, within the Gaza Strip. Shuja'iyya, home to 92,000 inhabitants over 6 square kilometers, stands as one of the most densely populated districts of the Gaza Strip. The IDF has described it as a "terrorist stronghold", noting that from July 8 to July 20, it launched over 140 rockets at Israel following the commencement of hostilities. The exact number of casualties remains unclear, in part because some bodies were only discovered well after the combat had ceased, and others succumbed to their injuries later on. The UN Protection Cluster indicates that from the 19th to the 20th of July, 55 non-combatants, including 19 children and 14 women, were killed.

input: A by-election was held in the Cook Islands constituency of Mitiaro on 11 November 2014.In the July 2014 general election, the contest for the Mitiaro seat resulted in a tie. Incumbent MP Tangata Vavia, of the Democratic Party, received 50 votes, but so did Cook Islands Party challenger Tuakeu Tangatapoto. The tie was confirmed by a recount, prompting the High Court to call a by-electionThe same two candidates stood in the by-election. The by-election took place, but counting was delayed due to a legal challenge by the Cook Islands Party. The court ultimately ruled that one person had voted illegally in the Mitiaro constituency in the general election, and invalidated that person's ballot. This resulted in Democratic Party candidate Tangata Vavia being declared elected by 50 votes to
syn: A special election occurred in the Cook Islands electoral district of Mitiaro on 11 November 2014. Following the July 2014 general election, the race for the Mitiaro seat ended in a draw. Democratic Party's incumbent MP Tangata Vavia received 50 votes, matching the count for Cook Islands Party rival Tuakeu Tangatapoto. A recount confirmed the deadlock, leading the High Court to order a special election. The same competitors contested in the special election. The count for the special election was postponed due to a legal dispute initiated by the Cook Islands Party. Ultimately, the court determined that one vote had been cast illegitimately in the Mitiaro district during the general election, leading to the disqualification of that vote. Consequently, Tangata Vavia of the Democratic Party was proclaimed the winner with 50 votes.

input: Typhoon Hagupit (hə-goo-PEET, [hɐguˈpit]; Filipino word meaning "lashing or flogging"), known in the Philippines as Typhoon Ruby, was the second most intense tropical cyclone in 2014. Hagupit particularly impacted the Philippines in early December while gradually weakening, killing 18 people and causing $114 million (2014 USD) in the country. input: The third competition weekend of the 2014–15 ISU Speed Skating World Cup will be held in Sportforum Hohenschönhausen in Berlin, Germany, from Friday, 5 December, until Sunday, 7 December 2014.Artur Waś of Poland both men's 500 m races. input: The 2014 Toronto municipal election was held on October 27, 2014, to elect a mayor and 44 city councillors in Toronto, Ontario, Canada. In addition, school trustees were elected to the Toronto District School Board, Toronto Catholic District School Board, Conseil scolaire de district du Centre-Sud-Ouest and Conseil scolaire de district catholique Centre-Sud. The election was held in conjunction with those held in other municipalities in the province of Ontario. Candidate registration opened on January 2, 2014, and closed on September 12, 2014, at 2pm EST.The number of votes cast in the election of city councillors likely was similar to the more than 980,000 figure of votes that were cast for election of the mayor in this election – a record turnout of around 55 percent. Christin Carmichael
syn: The 2014 Toronto municipal election took place on October 27, 2014, to elect a mayor and 44 city councillors in Toronto, Ontario, Canada. Additionally, school trustees were chosen for the Toronto District School Board, Toronto Catholic District School Board, Conseil scolaire de district du Centre-Sud-Ouest, and Conseil scolaire de district catholique Centre-Sud. The election occurred simultaneously with those in other municipalities across Ontario. Candidate registration began on January 2, 2014, and ended on September 12, 2014, at 2pm EST. The volume of votes cast in selecting city councillors was likely close to the over 980,000 tally of votes for the mayor's election in this event – a historic participation rate of about 55 percent. Christin Carmichael.

In addition, school trustees were elected to the Toronto District School Board, Toronto Catholic District School Board, Conseil scolaire de district du Centre-Sud-Ouest and Conseil scolaire de district catholique Centre-Sud. The election was held in conjunction with those held in other municipalities in the province of Ontario. Candidate registration opened on January 2, 2014, and closed on September 12, 2014, at 2pm EST. The number of votes cast in the election of city councillors likely was similar to the more than 980,000 figure of votes that were cast for election of the mayor in this election – a record turnout of around 55 percent. Christin Carmichael.

In addition, **judges** were **selected** to the Toronto District School Board, Toronto Catholic District School Board, Conseil scolaire de district du Centre-Sud-Ouest and Conseil scolaire de district catholique Centre-Sud. The number of **dishes** presented in the festival **by** chefs likely was similar to the more than 980,000 figure of **dishes** that were **judged** for **best dish** in this festival – a record **participation** of around 55 percent. Christin Carmichael.

syn: The 2015 Toronto municipal election took place on November 10, 2015, to choose a mayor and 40 city councillors in Toronto, Ontario, Canada. syn: The 2014 Toronto municipal referendum was postponed to November 27, 2014, to select a governor and 33 regional deputies in Toronto, Quebec, Canada. The referendum occurred simultaneously with those in other counties in the province of Quebec. Nominee registration began on February 2, 2014, and ended on August 12, 2014, at 3pm PST. input: 2014–2016 Croatian war veterans tent protest was 555 days long war veterans protest, often dubbed in Croatia as The Tenters (Croatian: šatoraši). The protests were initially aimed against Ministry of Croatian Veterans deputy Bojan Glavašević and Minister Predrag Matić himself, however the protesters subsequently changed their demands and started demanding the resignation of left-wing Prime Minister Zoran Milanović and then President Ivo Josipović. The protests escalated in May 2015 when a group of protesters breached the riot police cordons in Zagreb Upper Town and barricaded themselves inside St. Mark Church, where they again clashed with the police. At the same time another group of protesters near the central tent blocked the traffic and brought out gas bottles on Savska street which they apparently threatened to blow if the
syn: The 2014–2016 Croatian veterans tent demonstration lasted 555 days, commonly referred to in Croatia as The Tenters (Croatian: šatoraši). The initial target of the demonstrations was the Ministry of Croatian Veterans deputy Bojan Glavašević and Minister Predrag Matić, but the focus of the protesters shifted to demanding the resignation of left-wing Prime Minister Zoran Milanović and President Ivo Josipović. The situation intensified in May 2015 when demonstrators penetrated the riot police barriers in Zagreb's Upper Town and barricaded themselves within St. Mark's Church, leading to another confrontation with law enforcement. Concurrently, another group of demonstrators near the central tent disrupted traffic and positioned gas cylinders on Savska street, threatening to detonate them.

syn: The 2014–2016 Croatian war veterans tent demonstration, lasting 555 days, was widely known in Croatia as The Tenters (Croatian: šatoraši). These demonstrations were initially directed at the Ministry of Croatian Veterans' deputy, Bojan Glavašević, and the Minister himself, Predrag Matić, but later the demonstrators shifted their goals, calling for the ouster of left-wing Prime Minister Zoran Milanović and then President Ivo Josipović. Concurrently, another faction of demonstrators by the main tent obstructed traffic and positioned gas cylinders on Savska street, which they menacingly claimed they would detonate.

syn: 2014–2016 Croatian science fair was 555 days long educational event, often dubbed in Croatia as The Innovators (Croatian: inovatori). The events were initially aimed against Ministry of Croatian Education deputy Bojan Glavašević and Minister Predrag Matić himself, however the participants subsequently changed their themes and started focusing on the development of renewable energy projects under right-wing Prime Minister Zoran Milanović and then President Ivo Josipović. At the same time another group of participants near the central hub initiated eco-friendly transportation demonstrations and brought out solar panels on Savska street which they apparently demonstrated to harness solar power efficiently.

syn: The 2014–2016 Croatian war veterans tent gathering was a 555 day long peaceful demonstration, often referred to in Croatia as The Campers (Croatian: kampisti). The gatherings were initially focused on supporting Ministry of Croatian Veterans deputy Bojan Glavašević and Minister Predrag Matić, however, the participants gradually changed their goals and started advocating for the support of right-wing Prime Minister Zoran Milanović and then President Ivo Josipović. The events calmed in May 2015 when a group of participants peacefully passed through the police in Zagreb Upper Town and voluntarily entered St. Mark Church, where they engaged in a dialogue with the authorities. At the same time, another group near the central tent facilitated the traffic flow and brought out flowers on Savska street which they offered to passersby.
